A man supposed to be Daniel Hyer, about forty-five years old, and of sandy complexion, was found drowned at Pier No. 23 North River. His body was sent to the Morgue. Coroner Woltman will hold an inquest.

The Board of Apportionment held another inharmonious session yesterday. In accordance with a role recently adopted, it is necessary to give each member forty-eight hours' notice of a meeting, and to state the specific object in the call.

Kansas papers bring some details of the outrages at the scene of the Indian troubles. As a Leavenworth paper expresses it, "not only have the infernal red-skins been skirmishing along the Kansas border, but they have skipped out of the Territory on both sides, and on the Canadian, in the Texas Pan Handle, they have been giving the hunters a lively game."

John Dunn, one of the three members of Manhattan Lodge of Operative Plasterers, was placed on trial yesterday before Judge Sutherland, in the Court of General Sessions, charged with assaulting a plasterer named Michael Bowler, with intent to kill. The prisoner is jointly indicted with Daniel Cronin and George Reid, also members of the union, who demanded a separate trial.

One of the worst ventilated apartments used for public purposes, either in New-York or Brooklyn, is the room in which the Kings County Court of Sessions is hold. Yesterday, for a couple of hours, it was rendered almost unendurable by the presence of a vast crowd which had gathered to hear the investigation conducted before Judge Moore into the mental condition of Lizzie Lloyd King, alias Kate Stoddard, the alleged murderer of Chas, Goodrich.

People are very apt to be frightened about small dangers and careless about great ones. Let some imaginative reporter be allowed to work up a "sensation" based upon one or two deaths from acute diarrhea, suspected to be cases of cholera, and there is sent through a portion of the community a thrill of apprehension which only needs to be persistently repeated to develop into a genuine scare.

WASHINGTON, July 13. General orders from headquarters of the Military Division of Missouri, received at the War Department, announce that in consequence of the hostile attitude of the Comanche, Kiowa, and Cheyenue Indians, the existing orders fixing the limits of the Department of the Missouri are, subject to the approval of the President, so far modified as to extend the southern line of that department to the main Canadian River.
The internal revenue receipts yesterday were $571,007. Elijah Allen, an old resident of Medford, Mass., hanged himself yesterday.

California papers generally are by no means backward in singing the praises of their great and prosperous State, and of exulting in its annual increase of men and money. Some of its latest statistics are furnished by the San Francisco Chronicle, of the 6th inst., which says:

With the Mill River catastrophe fresh in our minds, nobody will be surprised to learn that the late heavy rains have resulted in another great flood in Western Massachusetts. Even a casual inspection of the reservoir at Mill River showed that it was a death-trap.
KISSINGEN, July 13. While Prince Bismarck was driving in the country toward the Saline Springs, at noon to-day, he was fired at by a young man.

HAVANA, July 13. The Diario says that, with the new tax of two and a half per cent. on capital and the ten per cent income tax, it is expected that by June 30, 1876, the debt created by the issue of $60,000,000 in bank bills on account of the Treasury will have been amortized, and $45,000,000 of other indebtedness paid.

So much has been said concerning the reappearance of the grasshoppers in Southern Minnesota and Northern Iowa that the general attention of the country has been turned in this direction, and a fear has been entertained that the wheat crop of Minnesota, which was last year variously estimated at from 24,000,000 to 28,000,000 bushels, would be seriously affected. The press of Chili and the Argentine Republic were still discussing the question of limits with respect to the disputed ownership of the Straits of Magellan. The Argentine Government was anxious that it should be declared neutral territory as the speediest and most friendly way of settling any question about it with Chili.
We have received $1 from Louis Cross for the Children's Fund. The amount has been sent to the Trustees.

SARATOGA, N. Y., July 13.--We have now an abundance of the muscular element, and a decided lack of the kind of weather which would admit the working off the superabundant energies which have been so long under restraint, A strong south-cast wind to-day again lashed the lake into a wild, billowy mass, in which no shell-boat could live five minutes.
Cholera infantum is very prevalent among the children of this city. The effort to establish public baths in Brooklyn does not meet with sympathy from the Board of Aldermen.
The warehouse business of the Custom-house for the month of June exhibits a falling off from that of the previous month. The entries were 2,299, and the withdrawals 6,198.

Dr. Pangloss pronounced this world to be the best possible under the circumstances, and people who are of a cheerful disposition believe him. Some philosophers, too, take a similar view, although it has undeniably many serious drawbacks.
Steam-ship Japan arrived at Yokohama 7th July, from San Francisco.

Messrs. Kelly, Wingate, and others engaged in the work of prosecuting Messrs. Gardner, Charlick, and Havemeyer, were in consultation yesterday at the law office No. 194 Broadway. It was deter mined that a vigorous effort should be made to procure new indictments against the Ex-Police Commissioners.

Albert Perry, a member of Company E, Third Regiment, N.G.S.N.J., has been lodged in the Union County Jail on a charge of embezzling the funds of the company. The company had a picnic on the Fourth of July, and Perry was Treasurer. When his accounts were examined it was found that he had appropriated $50 of the proceeds to his own use.

The mills of the Church Brothers are standing, but it is reported that their new mill is partly undermined. A wool-house and a barn belonging to them were carried away, with their contents, among which were several valuable carriages.

PANAMA, July 5. Up to the 28th ult. the public tranquility of this republic continued undisturbed, and the Government is busy preparing the reports concerning its administrative action, which must be presented to Congress.

Hon. Thomas J. Robertson, one of the United States Senators from South Carolina, has recently returned to Charleston, and in a conversation with a reporter of the News and Courier, of that city, has made a long and interesting statement concerning the feeling at Washington, in regard to affairs in the prostrate Palmetto State.

Mr. Theodore Tilton has addressed the following letter to the committee of gentlemen appointed by Mr. Beecher to examine the charges indirectly made against himself in Mr. Tilton's letter to Dr. Bacon:

The Philadelphia kidnapping still remains an unresolved, dreadful fact one suggestive of exceedingly unpleasant reflections, which, from their very unpleasantness, should receive thoughtful consideration.
HALIFAX, N.S., July 13.--The steamer Edgar Stuart, purchased for the Western trade, arrived yesterday.

PANAMA, July 5. The Fourth of July passed off very quietly in Panama. In the memory of the oldest American resident so dull an anniversary of the great national day has not been known. Beyond the fact of the United States Consul keeping open house and entertaining all who wished to do honor and respect to the flag, nothing occurred on shore to indicate that the Fourth was anything more than an ordinary working day.

The excursion of the members of the various Orange Lodges of this City and Brooklyn to Iona Island occurred yesterday without disturbance. The officers in charge of the excursion took precautions to guard against everything calculated to excite unfriendly feelings in their passage to and from the boats, and were untiring in their exertions to render the first annual excursion of the society a complete success.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 13. The heaviest loser at Chester is Dr. Heman S. Lucas, who estimates his loss at $10,000 by the partial sweeping away of his emery mill. The water went through the lower story of the mill, carrying off about $2,000 worth of emery.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 13. The 2:45 and 2:22 races, in each of which one heat was trotted last Saturday, came off to-day.

The season of what are really the "national sports" set in with the beginning of the month, and may be said to be at its height at the present moment. A series of regattas and the frequent matches of our yacht squadrons remind us that Englishmen who care for aquatics are betaking themselves to the water everywhere.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 13. A special to the Tribune says: "A fire at Manistee, yesterday afternoon, destroyed six stores and part of their contents, and the Eagle Hotel, which latter was set on fire. One of its proprietors was arrested this evening, charged with having caused the fire in his building. The total lose is about $20,000; partially insured.

The farewell game between the Boston and Mutual Clubs took place on the Union Grounds yesterday, and was witnessed by about 2,000 persons. It was closely contested throughout, and was won by the superior batting of the Bostons.

McCook, who was finally con firmed as Governor of Colorado, by one majority, at the last sitting of the United States Senate in executive session, has just arrived in Denver and assumed the duties of his office. Ex-Gov. Samuel H. Elbert, who has been East most of the time since his removal, returned some ten days ago.

The corner-stone of the Greenwood Baptist Church, Brooklyn, was laid yesterday afternoon. The new building is situated on the corner of Fourth avenue and Fifteenth street. Its dimensions externally are 74 feet by 81 feet, and the size of the audience room will be 70 feet by 72 feet.

Kansas has the honor of presenting to the American public the latest new party. This promising infant has not yet been named, but it may, for lack of a better title, be called the Independent Party of Kansas. It has begun its existence with a declaration of principles; life is not worth having without principles; and this is no feeble wail, but a stentorian cry from "the boundless prairies of the free West."

The Kinetic theory of gases, now generally received, assumes that the molecules of every gas are in constant motion at very high velocities, and that the pressure of any gaseous body upon the walls of the containing vessel is simply the sum total of the impulses of these molecules as they strike the walls and rebound.

These changes are daily more and more perceptible, especially in the most densely populated Eastern States, and merit the attention of the closest observers. Doctors, more, perhaps, than any other class of men, have enjoyed the privilege of some standing popular joke aimed against them. ITHACA. N.Y., Aug. 18. The Grand Lodge of I.O.O.F. convened at Wilgus Opera-house this morning at 9 o'clock. The session is better attended and more lodges are represented than for many years. A large number of ladies accompany the delegates.

The Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association of the M.E. Church opened its fifth annual camp meeting at this place on Friday last at 2:30 P.M. The place was crowded at that time, and nearly 450 tents had been hired for the season, which continues until next Monday. There were persons present from every city along the eastern shores of the Atlantic, and many even from the West.

The forty-second annual gathering of Methodists commenced to-day on "the old camp-ground." Of course, this being the first day, the attendance as yet is comparatively light, though fully 2,000 persons have already quartered themselves in the 150 tents and at the lodging-house. The latter building has ample accommodation for at least 200 persons, and no doubt it will be crowded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--The Signal Bureau presses on in its humanitarian work in the interest of commerce, agriculture, and science. Not content with providing for the safety of mariners on our own shores, Gen. LONDON, Aug. 25. The cricket match at Dublin was continued this morning with the Irishmen at the wickets. They finished their first innings with a score of 47. The Americans, who made 71 yesterday, added 94 to the count in their second inning. The Dublin Club then went to the bat for their final inning and completed it with only 31 runs, leaving the Americans the winners by 87.

The long-expected report of the Examining Committee of Plymouth Church appointed to investigate the charges preferred by Theodore Tilton against Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, was presented to the congregation last evening, and was received and indorsed with acclamation.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 28--The first Summer meeting of the Connecticut Stock-breeders' Association, at Charter Oak Park, closed to-day. Fully 15,000 persons were present, including several thousand in carriages. The 2:30 race was easily won by Everett Ray in three straight heats.
To the Examining Committee of Plymouth Church. DEAR BRETHREN: The Pastor of Plymouth Church, the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, addressed to us a letter, June 27, 1874, of which the following is a copy:

The baggage-laden trucks, the freshening breezes, the lessening heat, and the shortening twilight--that pleasantest gift of Summer--are far too obtrusive to allow Autumn to creep upon us unawares. But a few more short days and the Summer of 1874 is a thing of the past, a subject not for the daily newspaper, but for the historian. And certainly it will cut an important figure in history.

A Carlist correspondent writes to the London Morning Post from Tolosa, on the 7th inst., as follows: "Laguardia was taken by assault by the troops of his Majesty." So commences the official telegram announcing the capture of Laguardia, an important town situated within ten miles of Logrono. Three cannon, ammunition, a large quantity of arms, and other war material, as well as 400 prisoners, have fallen into the hands of the Royalists.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 30. The anniversary of the landing of the English colony at Sabino, Aug. 19, (O.S.,) 1607, was celebrated at Fort Popham on Saturday. About one thousand people were present. Hon. B.C. Bailey, of Bath, called the assembly to order, and Gov. Dingley was called upon to preside.

After much uncertainty, his Highness the Khedive has decided not to leave Egypt this Summer. Orders had been given to prepare his yacht for sea, an agent had been sent to Vichy to purchase horses and carriages and to engage apartments for him. Even the train which was to carry his personal baggage to Alexandria was ready, when, at the last moment, he decided to remain.

The death is announced of Frederick B. Conway, actor and manager of the Brooklyn Theatre, at his Summer residence in Manchester, Mass., yesterday morning. Mr. Conway was well and favorably known as an actor in this country and in England, and from his connection with the Brooklyn Theatre for the past ten years, he made many friends in this neighborhood, who will hear of his death with much regret.

PANAMA, Aug. 30. The state of the Isthmus, as well as the Republic in general, is quiet Business continues dull in Panama, partly from the financial difficulties into which most of our native merchants have fallen, as well as the scarcity of caontchoue and other exportable produce.

More than two months have passed since the abduction of little CHARLE ROSS. Although it has been so long a time, public interest in the affair has by no means subsided. If comparatively little has been recently said, it is because nothing has happened in connection with the affair. All the important facts that are known now were equally well known several weeks ago.

A cable dispatch announces the death of M. Guizot, the great Protestant statesman and historian of France. How important an epoch of the world's history is covered in this single life may be inferred from the fact that Guizot was born a month after the National Convention of the United States finished its deliberations over the Federal Constitution, and two months before that Constitution had been ratified by any of the States.

WORCESTER, Sept. 8. The Democratic State Convention meets here to-day, and the advance guard of leaders are on the ground to-night arranging the preliminaries. The business is all laid out, and the probability is that the convention will go through with its work in a straightforward and business-like way, and place its candidates in the field with enthusiasm. The delegates of the party have not met in convention with such flattering prospects as now.

PANAMA, Sept. 4. The news from Lima to the 27th of August is quite sensational. About 4.30 P.M. on the 25th the city was thrown into consternation by the news that a handful of desperadoes had attempted the life of the President. Varions letters had been received stating that there was a conspiracy to murder him; but the President refused to pay any attention to them.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 15.--Robert Toombs addressed a large meeting in this city this afternoon, indorsing the Louisiana revolutionists, and declaring his readiness to join them. Resolutions were passed indorsing them, and declaring that Federal interference was war on the Southern whites.

BOSTON, Sept. 15.--The great stallion race for the championship of the United States, a purse of $10,000 and four gold medals, was trotted at Mystic Park to-day. The weather was delightful, and the attendance was estimated by competent judges at 30,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15.--To-day was set down for the trial of Wm. Benton, the safe burglar. Benton was not present, and his counsel asked for a further postponement, which the court refused, ordering his recognizances ($2,000) to be forfeited. The only course now open is to rearreat Benton, provided he can be found.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 16.--Following up the victories of Monday and Tuesday, the Penn Government have proceeded to install new officers in all State positions in New-Orleans, excepting that of State Treasurer; the present Treasurer, Antoine Dubuclet, a colored man elected in 1870, and whose election has never been disputed, remains undisturbed.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 16.--The caucus of the Episcopal Convention last night did not adjourn until near midnight. So far as can be learned, nothing was done beyond a general bringing forward in a discussion of the various candidates for Bishop.

Daniel Henry Chamberlain, who has received, after a long contest, the Republican nomination for Governor of South Carolina, is a native of West Brookfield, in Worcester County. The report that he was a native of Worcester doubtless arose from the circumstance that he lived in that city several years and was a teacher in the high school there before he entered Yale College.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16.--Saratoga was declared full last night, out the delegates and visitors still keep coming in by every train. The conference, which began with such pleasant weather yesterday, is to-day clouded and dampened by a most unpleasant rain.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept.16.--The Republican State Convention effected a permanent organization last night by electing Senator S. W. Dorsey as President and W. W. Orrick as Secretary.

Simple as these materials are originally, they are made into more or less elegant toilets by the great variety of trimmings and facons, for which their very simplicity leaves ample scope.

The interesting facts published in regard to the alleged "corner" in corn, and the efforts of certain speculators to withhold wheat from the market in order to create an advance in prices, have resulted in numerous inquiries from merchants and distillers in this City for accurate information. A large number of letters have been received, and it is now generally conceded that the crop of corn will not be as large as in former years.

Another compliment has just been paid to the now defunct company of merchants and bankers who so long controlled British India, by the appointment of Sir RICHARD PHAYRE to the government of the Mauritius. Old John Company had certainly the art of breeding administrators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. The call of Gov. Moses for troops in South Carolina, yesterday, was by many supposed to be a trick to secure recognition by the General Government, or a card for political effect.

At the call of the German Cigar-makers' Union, and other trade unions, a public meeting was held at the Germania Assembly Rooms, yesterday, the object of which was to protest against cigarmaking and other factory work in tenement houses, owing to the danger to the health of the inmates.

Many favorable circumstances united to make yesterday a notable day to the church-going people of the Metropolis. The weather, though warm enough to suggest the commencement of Summer rather than its departure, was exceedingly pleasant.

About three weeks ago, on motion of Commissioner Voorhis, the Board of Police adopted a resolution directing the Chief Clerk to report to the board the rewards received by the detectives at present attached to the Central Office, as they appear on the records of the department.
Ex-State Senator Abraham Lent arrived in this City from Europe yesterday.

So many fortunes have been suddenly made in Russian railways, it has become the fashion for European gossips to invariably credit Russian millionaires with thrifty speculations in railway enterprises.

Through the medium of the press intimations have from time to time been received that the work of bringing order out of the comparative chaos now prevailing on Fourth avenue, and of adding two new tracks to the existing double track on the New-York Central, was rapidly approaching completion.

The Great International Transportation Company, which was chartered by the last Dominion Parliament, with a capital of $5,000,000, is beginning to move. The question was submitted to Jnstice Amasa J. Parker, of Albany, who gave the following opinion:

On Saturday next, Oct. 3, the annual Fall Meeting of the American Jockey Club will begin, and will doubtless attract the attention of the general public in a greater degree than any previous meeting held under the auspices of our popular local organization.

Christ Church is one of the oldest existing Episcopal churches in this City. It is even older than Grace, which for fifty years after the beginning of the present century was looked upon as second only in age and importance to Trinity.

A letter from Genesee to the Syracuse Standard, under date of Sept. 24, relates the following: "Yesterday, on the train on the Erie Railway which runs from Rochester to Dansville, and reaches here at 10 A.M., a most singular circumstance occurred.

It is announced officially by the Berlin War Office, says the Pall Mall Gazette, that private military societies are no longer to receive, as hitherto, any gifts of captured arms, there being no further surplus available.

Memory of the painful incidents connected with the epidemic of yellow fever in Memphis, Tenn., last year, is revived by the commencement of a suit for slander, brought by Paul A. Cicalla, who was Acting Mayor of the city at the time, against Michael Magevney for $50,000 damages.

ST. THOMAS, Sept. 16. San Domingo City dates of the 12th inst. are at hand. President Gonzales had just returned from his voyage to the Northern Provinces. The whole country is perfectly quiet. A Haytian steamer has arrived at San Domingo City, and by her the Dominican Commissioners will leave for Port au Prince to conclude the treaty of amity and commerce between the two Republics.
The following address was delivered by Senator Frelinghuysen, on Friday evening last, at the Republican primary meeting, in the First Ward, Newark, N.J.:

A curious trial, says the London Academy, has lately been held at the Tribunal de Commerce de la Seine relative to an Aldine Horace. M. Gromier, a bookseller of Bourg (Ain), purchased in a sale with some other books, which he bought for a trifle, an Aldine Horace, dated 1509.
Writing from Paris, Sept. 14, the correspondent of the London Standard says : "Parisian juries are just now in a stern mood, and will not hear of extenuating circumstances.

The Register General has just issued instructions to the Registers of Births and Deaths throughout England and Wales, between 3,000 and 4,000 in number, relative to the Act of Parliament on the subject of registration, which received the royal assent on the 7th of August, and comes into opera- tion on Jan. 1.
President Grant, Mrs. Grant, and Ulysses S. Grant, Jr., and Gen, Clinton B. Fisk, of St. Louis, are at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.
On Tuesday, Oct. 6, the Seventh Regiment will celebrate its semi-centennial anniversary. The following order has been issued:
We do not suppose that any properly-informed man, North or South, Republican or Democrat, can be perfectly satisfied with the present condition of the ex-insurgent States.
The Suffolk County Sabbath-School Association will hold its regular meeting at Port Jefferson on the 27th and 28th of October.

The Brooklyn detectives, aided by a private detective from New-York, have made another arrest in connection with the Terrini murder. The prisoner is Michael Caromonti, so long sought after by the Police, who claim that he is the man, or one of the men, who murdered the unfortunate Torrini on the night of the 12th of August, in Heyward street, near Bedford avenue, Brooklyn.
To-day the registration of voters begins in Brooklyn. Last year 67,000 names were enrolled, but this year a much larger enrollment is expected.

Col.W.N.Lewis, commanding Camp Supply, Indian Territory, and a communication received by that officer from Capt. W. Lyman, of the Fifth Infantry, commanding the train being sent to Gen. Francis Bacon conceived the idea of a society of men devoted to the culture of science. In his New Atlantis, where he describes the organization of that society, and its influence upon the destinies of a wisely-ruled people, he lifts science to the eminence of a State institution.
The schools of the Academy are open day and evening free, from the 1st of October until June. The Antique School will open on the 5th. All students must first enter the Antique School.

In his message to the Legislature of Oregon Gov. Grover says: "The salmon fisheries of the Columbia River are assuming such importance that I take occasion to call your attention to the subject. The product of these fisheries was scarcely noticeable four years ago, but last year it approximated $1,000,000 in export value, and for the season of 1874 exceeds $1,500,000.

The first performance of the season of Italian opera, under the management of Mr. Max Strakosch, took place at the Academy of Music last evening. In point of smoothness and symmetry the representation was a most satisfactory earnest of the fulfill- ment of Mr. Strakosch's promises.

Columbiana, Ala., telegrams to the Montgomery Advertiser give brief particulars of the accident on the Selma, Rome and Dalton Railroad, on Thursday, which was reported by telegraph. The south-bound mail train, it is stated, broke through Waxahatchie Bridge, fifty-five feet high, with but one span, at 4:30 in the morning. The whole train of three freight and one baggage car and the first and second-class coaches, and engine, is a wreck. The casualties were:

The elections which are taking place in the French Departments to fill vacancies in the Assembly are highly important incidents in the great political duel which is very far from being fought out between the Republic and its foes. Sometimes it is a Legitimist and a Bonapartist who are pitted against the Republican candidate; at others it is an Orleanist and a Bonapartist who divide the anti-Republican vote.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. The Daily Chronicle of this city has a chronic dislike of Civil Service reform, or any system which will keep the public offices out of political trade. This morning it has an editorial congratulation of the First Controller for a victory over the Civil Service reform system, so-called, and states that Mr. Taylor desired to make some promo-...
The first-class war steamer Tennessee, which is at present undergoing repairs at the Navy-yard, is expected to leave for China in May.
We have received the following dispatch from our Special Correspondent at New Orleans.

I have just been taking a holiday; am, in fact, engaged in that process even now. A journalist's holiday means change of work; and instead of writing to you from England I address a letter to you from France. I thought of going to Paris, but on reaching Calais I found that troops were collecting for a special purpose close by, at St. Omer.

The Fall meeting of the Fleetwood Park Association was inaugurated yesterday under favorable auspices. The Weather was fine and the track in good condition for fast trotting, and the attendance of spectators fair. There were two races on the pro- gramme, the first being a purse of $800 for horses that had never beaten 2:38, for which there were eight entries, and seven of them appeared for the contest.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 28 The jury of inquest in the Granite Mills disaster met at 2:15 P.M. Frank McGraw, Captain of the night watch, was the first witness. He testified as follows:

The annual town elections in this State are to take place on Monday of next week, and will excite as usual a considerable degree of interest, because of their bearing upon the Spring election. At these elections boards of selectmen are chosen, and as they have charge of the admission of new voters under the registry law, a political importance attaches to the contest is every town.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 28. United States detectives to-day captured a box containing a large amount of money and implements at the Adams Express Office, belonging and made by a notorious and extensive gang of counterfeiters, who have been operating in North Carolina, East Tennessee, West Virginia, and Kentucky.

The second annual meeting of the National Rifle Association, which commenced at Creedmoor, Long Island, to-day, will continue four days. The opening will be attended with much more agreeable surroundings than was last year's opening, on which occasion very few improvements had been made in the grounds further than the erection of targets.

The temporary stoppage of redemption by the National Bank Redemption Agency has subjected it to much unmerited censure. The permanent failure of the plan is predicted, and the officers and employes of the new bureau are denounced as incapable because they have not accomplished impossibilities.

The Lord Mayor of Dublin and the members of the Irish team of riflemen were entertained at a banquet in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening. The occasion did not properly partake of the character of a civic reception, though the Mayor of the city presided, but was rather the spontaneous outgrowth of the kindly regards in which the distinguished visitors are held by the citizens of Brooklyn generally.

A review of the Knights Templar took place yesterday at the Prospect Park parade ground, in presence of more than 15,000 persons. It had been arranged that this should be an event in every way worthy the high character of the organizations participating in it, and to add to the interest of the occasion, a competition drill for a silver cup was to be witnessed between such Commanderies as might see fit to enter.

The assessed value of the real estate in this City as equalized by the State Assessors, is $812,709,- 047. The following is a list of some of the largest buildings in this City, showing the assessed valuation for the past year and the amount of taxes paid:

Titled Europeans have carried off a great many American heiresses before now, but Mr. CHARLES PERKINS, formerly of Boston, enjoys the rare distinction, for an American, of marrying a princess. His brilliant success may have inspired others of his nation with the hope of being able to pick up an infants, or a duchess at the very least.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept.28. John H. Barnhill, of Tuscarawas, was nominated by the Repub- licans of the Thirteenth Ohio District for Congress to-day.

One cannot step out of one's house in these later times without encountering signs whose professed meaning it is not difficult to discover, but which have also a significance quite as interesting and not so obvious. These are the signs of the stores and shops, which in their present development are quite peculiar to our day, and in a great measure to our country.
Collector Love, of Jersey City, roports the receipt of $11,211,61 in taxes and assessments last week.
Hon. C.E. De Long, recently United States Minister to Japan, has delivered an interesting lecture in Sacramento, Cal., upon that country and its poople. We make the following extracts:

The records of commitments and convictions and fines imposed and collected at the various Police Courts throughout the City, and more particularly at Jefferson Market Police Court, appear, as already noted in THE TIMES, to be either carried away bodily or mutilated to such an extent as to render them absolutely useless.

At the regular meeting of the Methodist ministers yesterday the discussion of the question "How to Make the Sunday-schools More Effective?" was continued. Brother Weed, of Brooklyn, sug- gested but one session for children living in attract- ive homes, and two sessions for the benefit of poor children, who would be glad to be thus relieved from an unpleasant monotony.

The courtesies of the City do not appear to be exhausted in regard to the Lord Mayor of Dublin, but the possibility holds good that his Lordship may be considerably exhausted by this profusion of civilities.

A young German, named Gustave Maunz, of New-York, aged nineteen years, while returning from Jerome Perk, where he had been to seek em- ployment, was struck by a train of the New-Haven Railroad Yesterday and instantly killed.
The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce will be held on Thursday.

The majority of the prominent fire insurance companies adhere to their expressed determination of withdrawing from Chicago after Oct. 1. The President of one of the leading companies yesterday stated to a reporter of the TIMES that beyond all question fully nine-tenths of the insurance capital having risks at Chicago, aggregating nearly $140,- 000,000, would withdraw on the date mentioned.

The Court of Sessions Grand Jury of Kings County has found an indictment for criminal libel against Francis D. Moulton, at the instance of Miss Edna Dean Proctor. of Framingham, Mass. Miss Proctor appeared before the Grand Jury on Thursday. Her testimony was in substance a repetition of the facts embodied in the complaint upon which Miss Proctor's suit for damages against Mr. Moulton is founded.

We beg to recommend a "subject" to the writers of essays for monthly magazines, and they ought to be thankful to us for the suggestion, since it is quite clear that, as a general rule, they are very much at a loss for a peg on which to hang their valuable thoughts.

Although the "Liberals" met and adjourned at Albany yesterday with a discreet refusal to make nominations, the windy orators were not to be balked of their speech-making. The resolution adopted was used as a stalking-horse.
The Somerset County Fair opened yesterday on the fair grounds near Somerville, and will continue for three days.

Although abundant notice had been given that Cochrane would again meet in convention in this city to-day, the hotels were by no means overburdened with guests. Indeed, the number of persons visible about the Delavan was not only much less than when Cochrane met here before, but even smaller than is usually attracted by a meeting of the Canal Board. But the old...

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 29. In the Phelps case to-day, Treasurer Raiues was on the stand, and detailed the manner of the discovery of the larceny and the arrest of Phelps, and identified the drafts and other papers. No other testimony that was new was taken.

It is certainly no easy task for a manager to cater to the fitful appetites of audiences who demand a new local or sensational drama every week at least, besides a variety of other things in the vocal, terpsichorean, and "character-delineation" walks of the stage.

To-morrow nine-tenths of the Fire Insurance Companies in connection with the National Board of Fire Underwriters will suspend business in Chicago. Ever since the great fire of 1871, insurance companies have been more cautions in accepting risks in that city.

The introductory lecture to the regular Winter session of the Medical Department of the University of the City of New-York was given last evening in the college building, No. 426 East Twenty-sixth street, by Prof. John C. Draper, M.D., LL.D.

In accordance with the motion passed by the new Republican State Central Committee at Utica on the 23d instant, its officers, Hon. Edwin D. Morgan, President, Secretary Henry A. Glidden, of Orleans, and Hon. John N. Knapp, of Cayuga, Treasurer, met in Parlor E of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

The reply of the East-side Butchers' Association to the report of the Sanitary Committee of the Board of Health on the concentration and regulation of the business of slaughtering animals in this City, was yesterday submitted to the board. The objections of the Sanitary Committee to the continuance of the business in its present location are taken up seriatim and answered.

We hope our readers did not fail to examine the address prepared by Hon. Isaac H. Bailey, and adopted by the Utica Convention. There are facts and thoughts in it well worth the careful and sober consideration of the American people. Calm and clear in its statements, it embodies conclusive reasons why the Republican Party should be continued in power.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. The following statement has been obtained from the Customs Bureau of the Treasury Department: The law now on woolen and worsted goods is precisely the same as it has been since March 2, 1867, and is enforced in the same manner. The distinctions that are important to merchants are those relating to the designated classes of such manufactures and those that are not designated.

It was announced in the Surrogate's Court yesterday that the questions at issue in the matter of the will of the late Mr. Jacob Stiner had been satisfactorily settled among the members of the family without further recourse to law. It will be rememberad that Mr. Stiner met his death in January last by falling from a second-story window while endeavoring to escape from his burning house.

The chief features of the stock market yesterday were Lake Shore and Erie. The former stock advanced about two per cent., while the latter declined three points, though it subsequently recovered. The weakness in Erie was in sympathy with the decline in the London market, which was doubtless attributable to a raid on the part of the "bears," desirous of hammering the stock down to the lowest point possible before "settlement day."

No light has yet been thrown upon the mysterious disappearance of the records belonging to the several Police Courts except in the case of the Fourth District Court, Fifty-seventh street, where the volumes for the later part of 1860 and the first six months of 1861 were reported by the Clerk as missing.

On Monday next the Putnam avenue branch of the Brooklyn City Railroad will be opened for travel.
HONG KONG, Sept. 29. During the terrific typhoon that passed over here on the 27th inst., damage was done to American vessels as follows:
Bishop Loughlin will administer the sacrament of confirmation in the Catholic Church at Breslau, on Sunday next, Oct. 4.
A special meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment was held yesterday. All the members, consisting of the Mayor, Controller, Alderman Vance, and Tax Commissioner Wheeler, were present.

It is very seriously questioned here whether the National Congregational Council, which opens its sessions in this city to-morrow afternoon, is really congregational in its spirit. The Episcopalians, the Presbyterians, the Roman Catholics, all have councils as a natural growth from their belief that there is a power superior to any detached or separate church.

The Fall meeting of the National Rifle Assotion was opened at Creedmoor, Long Island, yesterday. Owing to the unfavorable weather, the number of spectators was very small, while not more than half the number who had entered in the "Judd" match, participated in the contests.

The Episcopal Diocesan Convention, which meets this morning in St. John's Chapel, is the most important local gathering of the year to the clergy and laity of this, the Metropolitan Diocese of the United States. For more than fifty years, if not, indeed, since the era of the revolution, New-York has held a commanding position in the councils of the Episcopal Church.

A special meeting of the Seamen's Protective Association was held yesterday afternoon at Botanic Hall, East Broadway, to take into consideration the case of the two sailors of the bark Billy Simpson, who refused to pay "blood money," as it is called. The President of the association, Dr. William F. Thoms, occupied the chair, and James M. Bennett acted as Secretary.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 29. The Committee on Information and Statistics for the District of Memphis make the following report to the National Cotton Exchange for September:

Williams, ...

DEAK, whose severe illness has been announced, is another instance of a phenomenon of frequent occurrence in history that the leading statesman of a people is often of directly opposite temperament and mental habits to those of his nation.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Sept. 29. The People's Convention of the Ninth Missouri District has nominated for Congress Col. P.A. Thompson, a wealthy farmer and Republican.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 29. The jury of inquest in the Granite Mill disaster met at 9:30 A.M.

Fire insurance companies assert that during the last sixteen years their business has, on the whole, been unprofitable. An analysis of the income and expenditures of some thirty-eight companies is said to show that during an average of thirteen years' business for each company, their collective losses have reached the sum of a million of dollars a year. Speaking more accurately,...

Juan Cessna, an Italian, was arrested on Sunday morning last by Detective Mullin, of the Central Office, and is now locked up at Police Headquarters, charged with having swindled a number of his ignorant countrymen by means of an ingenious confidence game. Cessna had three or four associates in his nefarious operations.

There was a time when the Bowery Theatre was the home of the legitimate drama, but the irresistible mutations of modern civilization have long since brought about another state of things. Like many of its more pretentious contemporaries, to-day the so-called "Old Drury" presents modern sensationalism and other claptrap to satisfy the peculiar tastes of its patrons, who differ from their fellowbeings of the west side only in that they need more highly-colored plays.
President Grant left the City last evening for Washington. The Pilot Commissioners met yesterday, but transacted no business of importance.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Sept. 30.--The Republican Convention of the Twenty-fifth District of Onondaga and Cortland met this afternoon and nominated Elias W. Leavenworth, of Syracuse, for Representative in Congress by acclamation.

Yesterday was opening-day at Arnold, Constable Co.'s dry-goods establishment, corner of Broadway and Nineteenth street. That is, it was opening-day for certain classes of their goods--for Paris cloaks and suits, as the announcement ran; also, for "a choice collection of furs and real India camel's hair shawls and scarfs."

Several prisoners were brought before Judge Donohue in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on writ of habeas corpus. Among the cases thus presented to the court was that of James O'Brien, already noticed in THE TIMES, on whose behalf it is claimed that he has been improperly detained in custody by Police Justice Smith without an examination.

The following proposals were opened yesterday by Controller Green for $2,384,000 New-York City stocks to redeem City bonds due in 1874, the interest to be seven per cent., payable in currency or six per cent, in gold, at option:

An interesting archaeological discovery has been made in Malta, and is thus described by Mr. C.A. Wright, Vice President of the Archaeological Society of that island: "During the course of excavation for building purposes ou the side of the Jesuits' Hill, near the Marsa, on the property of Signor Sacco, tho workmen lately came upon an ancient rock-cut cemetery, just below the surface of the ground.

The following is a copy of a petition to the President of the United States, now being signed by the leading merchants of New-York, Boston, and Philadelphia. It was prepared by Mr. John C. Hopper, Secretary of the "National Revenue Reform Association:"

Next Monday evening, Oct. 5, the usual evening schools will be opened throughout the City, to continue for a term of eighteen weeks. From the 21st September to the present time the work of examining, resistering, and classifying applicants for admission into these schools has been in progress, and will continue until the close of Saturday even ing next.

The opening of the regular term of Bellevue Medical College was signalized last night in the lectorium of that institute by an address, delivered by Prof. R. Ogden Doremus, before a large audience of ladies and gentlemen. Besides other distinguished personages, there were present, on either side of the speaker, the following members of the Faculty: Profs. Isaac E. Taylor, James R. Wood.

G. W. Lentz, Esq., of Pennsylvania, of the Committee on Lumber Statistics, made the following report to the Lumbermen's Convention, recently held in Saginaw, Mich., it being the result of careful investigation. It shows the quantity of standing white pine, hemlock, and hard-wood timber, east and west of the Allegheny Mountains, in Pennsylvania:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--A meeting of the depositors of the Freedman's Bank was held here last evening. This unfortunate institution seems to be the subject of hatred, distrust, and speculation, even to its end. It was stated last night that the city was rife with rumors as to the true condition of the bank to the effect that it would be months before a dividend would be declared;

Centre Church, the largest in New-Haven, was but partly filled at 3 o'clock this afternoon, the hour appointed for calling to order the second, or, as some count, the third National Congregational Council. The reason probably was that the attendance was almost entirely of dele gates, as the exercises were to be merely those of organization.
The Ohio Wesleyan Female College at Delaware, Ohio, is full to overflowing.

The Board of Police held a long session in the Central Office last night for the purpose of approving of the inspectors of election furnished by W. B. Hasbrouck, Chief of the Election Bureau. The First, Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and Seventh Districts were approved unanimously.
On Tuesday, notwithstanding the storm, 11,764 voters registered in this city.

The Grangers of Virginia have initiated their public operations by an attack at Danville, Va., on the middlemen (commission merchants and warehousemen) in the tobacco trade. This is the first overt act of our Patrons of Husbandry, and it causes a great sensation among all concerned. Danville is a large tobacco market, and a vast quantity of the staple produced in North Carolina, as well as in Virginia, is sold and manufactured there.
We have received the following despatch from our special correspondent at New-Orleans:

Among the candidates for the Republican nomination in the Second Assembly District of Kings County, is Mr. Jacob Cohen. The district is composed of the Third, Fourth, and Eleventh Wards. The Fourth Ward claims the nomination this year, and puts forward a popular candidate in the person of Mr. Cohen.

There is much in the "compromise" agreed on by the committees of the Republican and Democratic Parties in Louisiana that throws light on the real condition of affairs in that State. Although the document appears to be simple a common agreement, it bears evidence of being a recital of mutual grievances and pledges.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 30.--In the Phelps case, to-day, Homer Gorten testified that Phelps told him that his counsel had informed him he could not be taken to Albany from New-Jersey, otherwise he would have gone to South America.

Seventy-four complaints against Police officers were tried before Commissioner Disbecker yesterday, being all cases of neglect of duty and infractions of discipline. The only cases of public importance were as follows: Sergt. Patrick Dowdi. can, of the Fourteenth Precinct, was arraigned on a number of charges preferred against him by Inspector McDermott.

France is at this moment an object not only of intense interest, but of admiration to intelligent Germans. The revenues of the Government, and the comparative ease with which they are collected, in the midst of the effects produced by an exhausting and disastrous war, strike the German mind as something very remarkable. Some of the correspondents of the German papers have been studying the nature of the resources which France displays.

A singular story has just come to light which seriously compromises the character and integrity of a well-known stationer formerly doing business in this City. I.O. Seymour, formerly of the firm of Seymour, Kennard Hay, is charged with having fraudulently printed and uttered bonds of the town of Greenville. HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 30.--The Sharpe's Rifle Company of this city, recognizing the importance of a prompt acceptance of the challenge of Major Leach, of the Irish team, issue the following:

The ceremony of laying the corner-stone of the new church edifice about to be erected by the Methodist Episcopal Church on Forsyth street, between Canal and Bayard streets, took place yesterday afternoon with appropriate services. The site of the proposed building is partly that of the old one, recently taken down.
Patrick Lynch was arrested in New-Brunswick yesterday charged with atrociously assaulting and attempting to rob Jacob Smith.

Controller GREEN has addressed a lengthy communication on the subject of public improvements to certain prominent New-York bankers and merchants. That letter comes as the first installment of a somewhat tardy reply to an invitation addressed, nearly a year ago, to the Controller requesting him to take the public a little more into his confidence than he had been accustomed to do, ... and so clear away some of the current misrepresentation about his policy.

The Annual Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New-York held its first session yesterday, at St. John's Church, Varick street, under the presidency of Bishop Potler. There was a large attendance both of clergymen and lay delegates, but the business transacted did not pass much beyond preliminary matters in the nature of organization.

A letter in a French journal gives a highly interesting account of the marriage of the Russian Grand Duke Vladimir with the Princess Marie of Mecklenburg-Schwerin: "The nuptial ceremony took place the day after the arrival of the bride. On this occasion everything passed within the interior of the palace in presence of privileged guests.

At the usual monthly sale of Scranton coal, yesterday, 60,000 tons were sold. With a single exception, namely, in egg, the prices realized showed an advance over those of the previous month. Steam-boat sold at first at $5.30, but fell off to $5.20 and $5.17 .

There were about 800 persons present at the game between the amateur Flyaways and the Easton Club of Easton, Penn., played on the Union Grounds yesterday. The City of Santa Fe, meaning in English "Holy Faith," is situated on both sides of the Santa Fe River, a stream too small to be dignified with that name in the East. The city is surrounded by hills and mountains, sparsely covered with pinon, a species of pine, and cedar trees, few of which are higher than a man's head.

Rev. Dr. Rylance, at St. Mark's Church, yesterday, preached on "The Real Presence," being the third of a series of sermons, the two preceding ones having been upon "Confession" and "Absolution." There are really no new developments concerning the action of the Board of Fire Underwriters toward Chicago risks. Mr. Oakley, the President, and Mr. Montgomery, the General Manager, confirmed Saturday the announcement made in THE TIMES that the action of the board in suspending business in Chicago was not immediately due to the fire of last July.

The Democrats of New-York State have so seldom presented a candidate of good personal character to the community that we need not feel surprised at the pride which they now take in exhibiting Mr. TILDEN. Although Mr. TILDEN has long been treated with neglect by his own party, he is at this moment in high favor. His nomination at Syracuse was not, however, accomplished without difficulty.

The wildest excitement was created yesterday evening in the down-town districts of the City, from Fourteenth street to the City Hall, by the appearance of several wild steers, rushing furiously along the public thoroughfares in every direction, and tossing with their horns men, women, and children who came in their way high in the air.

Our Washington correspondent sends us the following: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4.--The political compromise in Louisiana has within itself a provision which it is thought will exercise a restraining influence upon the Conservatives. BOSTON, Oct. 4--Midnight.--Returns of delegates elected to the Worcester Convention, received up to this time, show 696, chosen and divided as follows: For Talbot, 394; for Loring, 116; anti-Talbot, 91; unpledged, 95. Some of the delegates counted for Talbot or Loring, or otherwise, are undoubtedly Butler men. A large number are known to be elected, but Loring's friends say that all of Butler's strength is promised to their man. The full convention includes 1,112 men.

ROME, Oct. 4.--La Liberta says the Pope's latter to President MacMahon was written in reply to an announcement of the withdrawal of the man-of-war Orinoque from Civita Vecchia. The Pope recognized the reasons for this measure, but declares that he would not have used the vessel to quit Rome under any circumstances.
The Newark dog-pound has been closed for the season. During September there were eighty-eight deaths in Paterson.

Simultaneously with the downfall of the chignon comes a revolution in the art of household furnishing. Of the first of these events, we must speak with extreme diffidence. It has been the custom with many people to place Turkey in the list of nations whose credit in the leading money markets of Europe has disappeared. When a few months ago the prospects of a new Turkish loan was gently foreshadowed, the idea was ridiculed by certain organs which claim to be authorities in European and American finance. It was treated by them as too preposterous to be genuine.

The most interesting feature in the polity of a free commonwealth is its citizen soldiery. In times of danger and civil commotion, it is to them that society instinctively turns for relief and feels in their strength its own security. In the ranks is found the vigorous manhood of the State. Its parades and occasions of festivity never fail to send through the whole community a warm and hearty glow of satisfaction.

RIO JANEIRO, Oct. 3.--The insurrection in the Argentine States continues, and is becoming formidable. The fleet has declared for Gen. Mitre, the leader of the movement. The insurgent forces have assembled at Chivilcoy and San Martin.

There was an incendiary fire in S.B. Coffin's block, on Railroad avenue and Hyde Park, near Boston, on Saturday night. The building, a wooden structure, was used as a boarding-house and diningsaloon. Loss $5,000, fully covered by insurance.

Mr. Hawthorne very properly styles his new book a romance. A novel certainly it is not; hardly a tale, unless in the sense in which everything that is told is so. It is, indeed, not quite within even the very wide and general term, narrative; for that, in its general acceptance, implies coherence, if not continuity; and Idolatry is neither coherent nor continuous.

PANAMA, Sept. 26.--A confidential commissioner appointed by the Chinese Government to investigate and report upon the condition of the coolies in Peru has arrived at Callao. It is said that this agent is a gentleman of education and experience.

RIO JANEIRO, Oct. 4,--The situation of affairs in Buenos Ayres is desperate. The Government is taking vigorous measures to suppress the insurrection. All the Government offices and commercial houses are closed. The Government has issued an order extending the time on all commercial credits.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5.--The port of Pascagoula, Miss., which has been rigidly quarantined against for some time, is reported entirely free from yellow fever by the Surgeon of the Marine Hospital Service, who was dispatched to that port by the Treasury Department to take proper precautions against the spread of the disease.

The Louisiana Commission or Engineers, which is charged with the duty of inspecting and surveying the levees, has just made its report, under which the Levee Company must act in repairing the levees. The commission report that nearly 100 levees must be rebuilt this year, (the year beginning Oct. 1.). These levees represent 1,967,500 cubic yards, and their construction will cost $983,750.

At 2:40 yesterday afternoon a fire occurred on the roof of the building No. 38 Canal street, the first floor of which is occupied as a hardware store by John Hasmayer. Damage to stock, $500; insured. The Grand Jury of Ramsey Counts, Minnesota, has indicted Ex-State Auditor Charles McIlrath for felony and malfeasance in office. The indictments are twenty-six in number. Two of these charge him with felonious entry upon the duties of his office before giving the required bonds and sureties.

There is an extraordinary mania in London just now for starting clubs. Almost every morning a new one is advertised in the papers, and it must be supposed that clubs would not be established unless it were thought likely that they would secure a sufficient number of members to make them pay. It is curious to observe how certain streets are gradually being absorbed in this way.

William L. Cole, one of Kelly's candidates for Aldermen at Large, came to this country when young, and worked in differentcities as a compositor. About thirty years ago he settled in this City, and in 1849, in connection with the late Patrick Lynch; started the Irish American newspaper. During the late war he served as a paymaster in the United States Army, with the rank of Major.

A traveler in Vermont, stopping at a hotel recently, ordered supper. The meal was very inferior one, and at its conclusion, which was soon reached, be stepped np to settle for it. "Well," said Boniface, with alacrity, "I hope son had a good supper." "Yes." replied be, musingly, " the supper averaged first rate; the butter was strong, and the tea was weak."

More than usual attention has lately been called to the subject of deficiences in the preparation of boys for college. Such deficiencies may be divided into two classes. One class consists of defects which have always existed. The other is composed, in a greater or lesser degree, of those peculiar to our own time. It is of the latter sort that we shall here principally speak.

After repeated conventions and consultations, the Temperance State Executive Committee have declared in favor of the State ticket with Myron H. Clark at its head. All attempts to convince these men of their folly have failed. They will not heed the protests of the Republican press, nor do they respect the timely admonitions from Gerrit Smith.

This opinion of the court, prepared with great care and most ably written by the learned Chief Justice Ryan, was deemed the most important document that ever emanated from that court.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 1, via HAVANA, Oct. 11. Gen. Porfirio Diaz has reconsidered his determination to retire from public life. He is in the city, and will take his seat in Congress. The division between the Liberals and Conservatives still exists. It is said that President Lerdo desires to be elected for another term.

The order issued recently by the Commissioners of Police, and still more recently rescinded, directing members of the force to wear their uniforms at all times, is suggestive of something more than a mere question of discipline. We do not doubt the unpopularity of the order. And it is quite clear that in many cases it entailed hardship and inconvenience upon the men.

Last night we had one of those brilliant artistic fetes so dear to the hearts of Parisian journalists and members of fashionable society. A grand representation was given at the Salle Ventadour in honor of and for the benefit of Dejazet, the comedienne. Many of myelderly readers may open their eyes at this name, and ask themselves if this can be the Dejazet whom they saw in their youth.

Right Rev. Dr. Whitaker, the Episcopal Bishop of the State of Nevada, preached yesterday morning in St. James' Church, East Seventy-second street. The text was from the Second Epistle of St. Peter, third chapter and eighteenth verse: "Grow in grace." The word "grace," the preacher said, is used in the Bible in different connections and with various meanings.

Early yesterday morning, a disturbance occurred in the oyster and dining saloon of Mulligan Marston, No. 2,383 Second avenue, during which John Carr, aged thirty-two, of Seventy-fourth street and First avenue, was stabbed in the wrist with an ice-pick by William Mulligan, one of the proprietors, and was severely wounded. Mulligan was arrested, but Carr refused to make a complaint against him and he was released from custody.

Unitarianism in America is of comparatively recent growth. Almost all the other churches, including the orthodox as well as those professing liberal principles, had acquired a foothold in this country, before the promulgation of Unitarianism, as a separate form of belief. The causes of this are not hard to find. Like all new countries, America was peculiarly the home of the working classes.

Every one who knows anything of the commercial necessities of this City will agree with Controller GREEN in the opinion expressed in his late letter to several prominent citizens, that "work on the docks and piers should be pushed forward with due regard to the modern commercial necessities for cheapening transshipment."

A number of inspectors of election against whom complaints were preferred by Police Officers and citizens, were formally cited to appear before the Board of Police yesterday to answer. The majority of them did not appear, and on the evidence against them being heard, were formally removed from office on motion of Commissioner Disbecker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. The telegram of Gov. Brown, of Tennessee, to the President, a few weeks ago, requesting that the United States withdraw action concerning the trial of the Gibson County outlaws in order that the State might deal with them, having been referred to the Attorney General and by that officer referred to the United States Attorney for the Western District of Tennessee.

BOSTON, Oct. 12. There were three Congressional Conventions held to-day in this State instead of two. The principal one, of course, was that in the Sixth District, held in Newburyport; where Gen. Butler was fighting for a nomination. With his usual skill in political matters, he succeeded in carrying the convention with the exception of a few votes.

There is a considerable proportion of the Democratic vote of this City drawn from the ranks of honest, reputable, and intelligent men. The Tammany Hall delegates from the First Assembly District, cemprising the Fourth Senatorial District, met at No. 173 Madison street last evening, to nominate two Aldermanic candidates. On a vote being taken the poll stood as follows: Patrick Lysaght, 67; Edward J. Shandley, 67; Edward Kenefick. 23, and Frederiek Zimmer, 18. On motion the nomination of Lysaght and Shandley was made unanimous.

Postmaster General Jewell, among other salutary reforms in his department, has begun to sweep out the claim agents. Everybody who knows anything about the exasperations, delays, and costs of these middlemen will wish the Postmaster General success in his somewhat difficult reform.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Oct. 14. The returns up to this hour (2 A.M.) indicate that Charles Foster is elected by a small majority.

We allude to CORTINA, not to BUTLER. Senor CORTINA is very well known along a good portion of our South-western frontier as an able and skillful cattle-thief; nay, is not without friends who believe him a great and good soldier, and who would follow him to the mouth of the pit if he wished, so complete is their confidence in his luck.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 13. In the Phelps case this morning, William E. Warren, the expert accountant who examined the books of the Treasurer's office, was called, and testified to making such examination. He stated that the full amount of the defalcation was $304,000.

It was on the last day of May, 1873, that Gov. DIX signed the Civil Damage Liquor bill. It was nearly a year after the bill thus became law in this State that the first conviction under its provisions was obtained. Mrs. TILLY, of Port Washington, Queens County, had, we believe, the distinction of being the first to show how wives could punish liquor-dealers who helped their husbands to get drunk.

As already shown in THE TIMES by extracts from the German City papers, the German organizations are thoroughly disgusted with the action of the Tammany County Convention on Saturday, and are determined to repudiate the nominations there made. Last night a meeting of the convention composed of delegates elected by the various citizens and reform organizations in the different wards and Assembly districts was held at the Germania Assembly Rooms.

At the opening of the afternoon session the President announced the appointment of Rev. O.P. Thackara, of Florida, in the place of Dr. Scott, also of Florida, upon the Committee on the State of the Church.

The horse-holders of New-York have been agreeably surprised by receiving this Autumn, for the first time, excellent native grapes the Concords, Isabellas, and other varieties at prices of from three to five cents per pound, retail. This is partly owing to the opening by railroad and steamboat of new regions of supply of fruits, vegetables, and game.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 13. The contest in the Cleveland (Twentieth) Congressional District, between the two rival candidates for Representative, during a few weeks past, has been one of the most spirited that ever occurred in this section of Ohio.

Gen. C.C. Augur, United States Army, is at the Glenham Hotel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. A special to the Chicago Times from Indianapolis, Ind., says the elections passed off quietly at nearly all the polls in that city. For one week both parties had been preparing for the occasion and last night the old politicians were heard to say that no such interest had been manifested by the people generally in any election since 1864.

COLUMBUS, Oct.13. Private advices from Republican sources in Toledo concede the election of Frank H. Hurd (Dem.) to Congress, defeating Albert M. Pratt, (Rep.)

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 14. Owing to scratch ing, at this hour 1 A.M. it is impossible to give any definite returns, as none of the precincts have yet finished counting. It is generally considered, however, that the full Republican County ticket has been elected The vote on the State ticket is in doubt.

SANTANDER, Oct. 13. A report has reached here that Gen. Dorregaray, with 800 Carlist troops, has gone over to the Republican army. The report lacks confirmation, but it is stated that two Carlist battalions have surrendered at Algorta, and that others are offering to surrender upon condition that the Fueros is respected.

The fourth day of the Fall meeting of the American Jockey Club passed off successfully. The six races were all closely contested. The weather was raw and cold, but notwithstanding this drawback, there was a fair proportion of spectators. The track was in admirable order.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. The election news was very quietly received here to-day, for not much came last night, and the dispatches in the morning papers contained little information. Only general results have been learned up to this evening.

LONDON, Oct. 14. The race for the Middle Park Plate came off at the Newmarket meeting to-day and was won by Plebeian. Per Se came in second and Galopin third. A capital start was effected, all getting off well together. Plebian won, after an exciting contest, only a head in advance of Per Se, who was but the same distance in front of Galopin. Holy Friar was a good fourth.
BOSTON, Oct. 14. The annual meeting of the American Social Science Association commenced this morning, Judge Wells, of the Supreme Court, occupying the chair.

The Democratic Congressional Conventions will be held this evening. The state has been made up by Kelly and Morrissey, and if a favorite or pet of their own is not popular among the Democratic masses of a district they will endeavor through their henchmen to force the Convention to nominate him.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 14. The returns from this (Pulaski) county show the election of the entire Democratic Conservative ticket, by from 700 to 1,000 majority.

The House of Clerical and Lay Deputies met yesterday at 11 o'clock. The Republicans of New-Brunswick and vicinity assembled in Masonic Hall, in that city, Tuesday night to ratify the nominations of Hon. George A. Halsey for Governor, and of Hon. Amos Clark, Jr., for Congress. The large hall was fairly packed with a most enthusiastic audience.

Last Saturday afternoon Judge Wheeler rendered a decision in the case of George Brown vs. Susan E. Stevenson, giving judgment for defendant. The action involved the title to the International Hotel property. The Montgomery Avenue Commissioners awarded $57,000 damages for appropriating a portion of the property for street purposes to the supposed owner, the defendant.

The Fall regatta of the University camp off this afternoon. Lake Saltonstall had been selected for the races, and long before the appointed time a dense mass of spectators lined the shores. The best location for observation was at a bend in the lake, about half a mile up on the east side.

Yes, in New-England. "White trash," as trashy and worthless as any in the world. It is something of an anomaly, and consequently all the more worth chronicling. Imagine a tract of land among the pines and cedars of northern Maine, half a day's journey through the untamed forests, beyond any traveled road.

The review of the Volunteers, which was announced for last Sunday, took place on that day, which was bright and sunshiny, and attracted an immense concourse of people, the novelty being on this occasion that they marched before their comrades of the drafted contingent of Volunteers destined for service in the field.

A large audience assembled evening in the large hall of the Cooper Institute to hear the first delivery of Mr. Parton's new lecture entitled "Kings of Business." Like Mr. Parton's other productions, his new lecture abounds in anecdote and illustration, is full of wit rather than wisdom, and depends for its interest and value especially upon the manner in which the subject is handled.

There is one matter on which the Assembly committee now in session, and the various persons who address them on taxation, are in entire agreement. And that is, that the system of taxation for personal property in this State is a delusion and a farce.

John Purcell, the murderer of William Kiernan, was placed on trial for felonious assault, in the Court of General Sessions yesterday. Purcell, who is an ill-looking desperado, was convicted before Recorder Hackett in June, 1869, of murder in the first degree, having shot William Kiernan opposite No. 109 Sheriff street, in a street fight, on the 24th of May of that year.
The rapid increase of the City debt since September, 1871, has been a stock subject of criticism with newspapers and public men who had cause to regret the downfall of TWEED and CONNOLLY.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. It is expected that judgment will be passed upon Count Von Arnim shortly before Nov. 1. The Count occupies two rooms in the hospital where he is confined. He is treated with more general severity and is more closely watched than heretofore. His intercourse with his family has been stil further restricted.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 14. The election in Indiana has proved to be a perfect Waterloo for the Republicans. The returns received before midnight last night give no indications of the completeness of the defeat, and as the later dispatches became known and especially when the news from the counties of a semi-official character came pouring in today, the Republicans were perfectly overwhelmed and the Democracy could hardly realize the victory they had achieved.

The Democrats, it is now conceded, have carried their State ticket in Ohio by from 15,000 to 17,000 majority, and have made a gain of seven Congressmen. These are SAVAGE in the Third, McMAHON in the Fourth, HURD in the Sixth, POPPLETON in the Ninth, VANCE in the Eleventh, and PAYNE in the Twentieth District. The delegation will stand 14 to 6.

The Jersey City Presbytery assembled at 2 o'clcck yesterday afternoon, in the Presbyterian Church on Third street, Jersey City, to proceed with the trial of Rev. John S. Glendenning, of the Prospect Avenue Church, on charges of immoral conduct preferred against him by the late Mary E. Pomeroy. The accused minister was present, betraying no feeling of anxiety as to the result, even laughing at times with those around him.
Col. N.B. Bartram and N.C. Pond were yesterday elected School Trustees for the village of Port Chester, in the place of H.M. Henderson and Philip Rollhause.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. Ohio the temperance plank was more than the Republicans could carry. The Democrats favored license, and the Republicans opposed it. The Democratic majority ranges from 12,000 to 15,000, giving them twelve of the twenty Congressmen and in Nebraska the Republicans carry the State by a large majority, electing their members of Congress and a majority of the Legislature, thus securing a United States Senator in place of Tipton.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 14. The result in this State is not more surprising to Republicans than to Democrats. Gov. Allen was elected on a majority of 817, and it was expected that the large stay-at-home vote would come out in strength sufficient to place the State on its proper Republican footing.

A reporter of THE TIMES yesterday conversed with a number of Democrats who sympathize with the movement inaugurated against Tammany Hall. From the expressions of sentiment made in many circles he was convinced that the feeling now ripening into denunciations of Tammany springs not exactly from mere political motives.

The special telegram sent to THE TIMES last evening has advised the reader of the rather extraordinary position assumed by Judge Ballard, of the United States District Court, in his charge to the Grand Jury. It is an address, in the language of the Louisville Ledger, a bitter Democratic sheet, which "contains much sound Democratic doctrine, to which the firmest adherent to the Jeffersonian creed can hardly except."

In pursuance of the call signed by a number of the Peter Woods' delegates to the Tammany County Convention, a large indignation meeting was held last evening at the New-York Assembly Rooms, First avenue and Twenty-second street, to protest against the exclusion of that delegation from the convention.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 14. The Woman Sufrage Association meeting to-day was attended by a large audience; and much interest was shown in the proceedings. Col. Forney and Mrs. Gillet addressed the convention. Regarding the progress of the cause in Michigan, they are hopeful that the female suffrage clause in the new Constitution will be adopted.

The coming Winter promises to be one of not less than usual activity in the studios and art ateliers of Rome. Yesterday the Board of City Works made a requisition for the issue of bonds amounting to $115,000, for extending the distribution of water in various parts of the city.
The Pennsylvania Railroad Company have issued a notice that after noon, Oct. 18, all trains, in either direction, when ranning on double track, will keep to the right.

The acceptance of public office imposes a sacred obligation. It is the solemn duty of the incumbent faithfully to discharge the trust which is confided to him by the people, and which he voluntarily takes upon himself. A public officer may make mistakes all men are liable to err but for the open, willful neglect of duty, there is no excuse.

The Cunard steam-ship Bothnia, which left Liverpool Oct. 3, and Queenstown Oct. 4, reached this port yesterday, with mail news later by two days.
