SANTANDER, 15. It is reported that a Carlist magazine at Arteaga has exploded.

The exposure in THE TIMES a few days since of the bogus-appeal business, carried on by the Custom-house brokers of New-York and elsewhere, has had a marked effect, and no such appeals dated since that publication have been received at the office of the Commissioner. In disposing of the appeals on file, however, further interesting disclosures have been made.

At the last session of the Legislature of this State, an act was passed by which the charter of the City of New-Orleans was materially changed. Among other things it was provided that the Mayor and city officers should hereafter serve for four instead of two years, and that they should be chosen at the regular State election.

Much has been said, and much will doubtless still be said, about "Caesarism" and the desire of the President to secure a re-election in 1876. The facts of the case seem, however, to lie in a very small compass.

It is nearly ten years since the body of Mr. LINCOLN was laid in the earth at Springfield, Ill. The funeral service of April 19, 1865, was the most impressive every held in the country. By common consent, the people throughout the land assembled in their churches, and prayers, tears, eulogies, and dirges attested the affectionate grief of the nation.
Gen. John Love, of Indiana, is at the Gilsey House.

In an important address at the semi-annual conference of the Latter Day Saints lately, Elder ORSON PRATT made an elaborate defense of polygamy as practiced by the Mormons. ORSON PRATT is one of the hierarchy who govern the Mormon community.
There was frost all over Alabama Wednesday night.

SPRINGFIELD Ill., Oct. 15. An immense concourse assembled to-day to witness the unveiling of the statue of Abraham Lincoln, which was recently placed in position on the National Lincoln Monument in Oak Ridge Cemetery. The weather was propitious, and the occasion was one which will be long remembered by all who had the pleasure of participating in it.
In his speech accepting the Republican nomination for re-election to Congress in the Ninth District of Massachusetts, Hon. George F. Hoar said:

Charles J. Everett was unanimously nominated for Congress by the Republicans of the Four teenth District, at Middletown, on Wednesday, the 14th inst. Mr. Everett is now Treasurer of Orange County and cashier of the Goshen Bank. He is said to be exceedingly popular at home, and the Repub- licans of the district confidently predict his election.

Between now and the 1st of November, the Board of Apportionment is required to decide upon the appropriations for the City Government for 1875. On their action depends the rate of taxation for next year, and as the ability to pay taxes is decidedly on the decrease in the City of New-York, their proceedings will be watched with some little anxiety.

The annual meeting of the American Church Missionary Society (Protestant Episcopal) was held yesterday in the Church of the Ascension, Fifth avenue and Tenth street. After devotional exercises, Rev. William R. Nicholson, D.D., Second Vice President, called the meeting to order. The minutes of the last meeting having been read and approved, the Executive Committee presented their fifteenth annual report, including an exhibit of the society's finances.

VIENNA, Oct. 16. The Italian Consul at Bucharest has refused to open negotiations for a commercial treaty while the Jews in Roumania are deprived of their civil rights. The American Consul, Mr. Peixotto, has taken the same stand.

The convention was called to order at 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning, at the rooms of the NewYork Chapter, No. 128 Broadway. Mr. George B. Post, of New-York, was elected President pro tem. The first thing in order was the unfinished report of the Committee on Professional Practice. This report had come over from the executive session of the previous day.

LONDON, Oct. 15. The Empress of Russia has arrived in this country, and is now at Buckingham Palace.

The committee recently appointed by the American Society of Civil Engineers to investigate the subject of rapid transit for passengers, and for improved methods of delivering, storing and distributing goods and freight in and about the City of New-York, held its first session yesterday, at the rooms of the society, No. 63 William street.

Douglas Taylor sued to recover from The Mayor, , salary as Commissioner of Jurors. The issue raised by the pleadings in the case was. To what amount of salary was the plaintiff entitled under the law? In 1970 the salary of the Commissioner of Jurors was fixed by statute at the same rate as that of the Recorder and City Judge, $10,000 per annum.

In the Board of Aldermen yesterday, Mr. Kehr offered a resolution requesting the Mayor to appoint a German to the office of Excise Commissioner. He said he would not be satisfied with a viva voce vote, and that the ayes and noes should be called upon the question. The motion called forth an animated debate.

The Tammany Hall Congressional Convention of the Fifth Congressional District met last evening at No. 158 Chatham street, with Harry Howard, Ex-Chief of the old Fire Department, in the chair. Speeches wore made by County Clerk Walsh, Deputy Coronor Shine, and Mr. Brogan. Edwin R. Mead was unanimously nominated for Congress.

A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was convened yesterday, to inaugurate the opening of the Court of Arbitration, under Judge Fancher. Hon. William E. Dodge presided. The rooms of the Chamber were densely crowded with the members and leading merchants of the City. Several members of the Bench and Bar were also in attendance.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15.--The second annual session of the Woman's Congress, called under the auspices of the Association for the Advancement of Women, commenced in this city to-day in the First Methodist Church, which was comfortably filled with an audience composed mainly of ladies.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. The match race for $5,000, mile heats, best three in five, in harness, between the stallions Jay Gould and Bashaw, Jr., took place this afternoon over Bishop's Herring Run course. Tho attendance of spectators was large, over 3,000 persons being present, and the Weather was bright and bracing.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 15. From the best estimates that can be made to-night, the Legislature will stand as follows: Senators holding over Republicans, 16; Democrats, 8. Elected Republicans, 8; Democrats, 12; Independents, 3; doubtful, 3.

The explosion of gunpowder on the canal at Regent's Park has, of course, been very unpleasant for the people of that region, but the inhabitants of London generally have every reason to be thankful for it, inasmuch as it has given them a timely warning of the perils to which they are exposed by their own carelessness; and it is to be hoped that this will not be neglected.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 16. The Tenth Congressional District Democratic Convention, at Greenfield to-day, adjourned after appointing a committee to select a candidate and report to the public any time before election.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 16. A dispatch from Fort Garry announces that a declaration of outlawry has been issued by the Court of Queen's Bench in Manitoba against Louis Riel. This action disposes of the question whether Riel is or is not a fugitive from justice, and of any claim he might make to sit unmolested in the House of Commons.

They are narrated, not as illustrating any large degree of skill in the use of the rifle by our soldiers in time of war, but as indicating the average effect of the rifled musket in the hands of the volunteer soldier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. Information has been received that the International Postal Convention recommends the application by all nations of the metric system to the weighing of mail matter passing between different countries. It is recommended that the equivalent of the half ounce, which is the unit of letter postage in the United States and some other countries, be fifteen grammes, and that fifty grammes be the unit of the weight for printed matter.

A cable telegram which we published the other day will be read with satisfaction by a large class in this country. It announced that the Italian Consul at Bucharest, the capital of Roumania, had refused to open negotiations for a commercial treaty while the Jews in that country are deprived of their civil rights, and that the American Consul has adopted a similar course. This is a step in the right direction.

Rev. Joseph T. Duryea was born on Long Island, in 1833. He prepared for college in Union Hall Academy, Jamaica, Long Island, the once wellknown school of which Henry Onderdonk and John Brinkerhoff were principals. In 1852 the subject of this sketch entered Nassau Hall, Princeton, N.J., from which he graduated as a valedictorian in 1856, entering the Theological Seminary at the same place in the following September.

A very instructive and interesting lecture on "Southern California" was delivered last evening in the large hall of the Cooper Institute by Mr. J.A. Johnson. The attendance was not as numerous as desirable, but those present had the opportunity of enjoying an entertainment which conveyed an abundance of such valuable information as comes of travel and actual experience.
A kerosene oil lamp exploded at the residence of Mrs. Denham, on Kosciusko street, last evening, but the fire which it kindled was put out before much damage had been done.

The Republican Aldermanic Convention of the Seventh Senatorial District, met last night at No.457 Fourth avenue, to nominate an Alderman in place of Hon. Jackson S. Schultz, who had declined. Hon. Robert G. Cornell called the convention to order, and John Pullman, the Secretary, called the roll.

Yesterday was the twelfth day of the session of the Jersey City Presbytery for the trial of Rev. John S. Glendenning. The session opened at 1 o'clock, the usual hour, with prayer. A long debate ensued over a resolution offered by Dr. Imbrie, allowing the prosecution, after the close of the case for the defense, to offer rebuttal testimony. A motion to lay the resolution on the table was adopted.

The third Fall meeting of the Prospect Park Association was inaugurated yesterday, with fine weather and the track in splendid order. Two good races were on the card, with large fields of horses, and excellent sport was the result. The first race was the three-minute purse, which had twenty-one entries, out of which nine started. They were New Dorp, T.J. Stevens, Effie Dean, Cheston, Hampton, Compeer, Falmouth Boy, Catskill Girl, and Arthur.

The reputation of the concern is inter-continental; their scales penetrating not only all parts of this country, but foreign countries as well.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 27.-- The Baptist Missionary Convention of the State of New-York is holding its sixty-seventh anniversary at Hornellsville, Steuben County. The Pastor's Conference was held to-day, there being about 225 clergymen present. The following-named were chosen officers: Chairman, Rev. J. Butterfield, of Oswego; Secretary, W.B. Wright, of Seneca Falls; Treasurer, Rev. E.H. Johnson, of Ballston Springs; Librarian, Rev. John C. Ward, of Oxford.

At the meeting of the Board of Health yesterday a permit was granted to the Trustees of the Methodist Episcopal Church in Harlem to disinter and remove the remains now lying in the graveyard surrounding the church building in One Hundred and Twenty-fifth street, between Fourth and Lexinton avenues, the disinterment and removal to be accomplished duriug the month of November.

The lovely weather which has prevailed of late has been most propitious for the display of the rare toilet novelties for which this firm is noted. On the right of the main entrance to their store, corner of Broadway and Ninth street, is a glittering array of jet in all the leading designs of gimps, passementeries, fringes, collarettes, pockets and belts, ranging in price from nine cents up to $6 per yard.

The Jersey City Board of Aldermen met last evening for the first time in three months. Alderman Burnsted presided. The numberless applications for licenses were referred to Aldermen Cable, Helms, and Meyer.

One of the nominations which attract most attention in Brooklyn is that of Mr. S. B. CHITTENDEN for Congress in the Third District. This is the only district usually counted safe for the Republicans. This year, there being a vacancy caused by the resignation of Gen. WOODFORD, the regular Republican Convention nominated a man by the name of COCHEU for the short term and Mr. P.W. OSTRANDER for the long term.

The trial of Isaac Badeau, Ex-Collector of Taxes of Brooklyn, for embezzlement, was resumed yesterday, before Judge Neilson, in the City Court, Ex-Judge Van Cott appearing for the prosecution. Badeau's counsel consisted of ex-rebel Fellows, D.P. Barnard, J.U. Shorter, and Abel Crooke.

The sixth anniversary of the Ladies' Domestic Missionary Relief Association, a valuable branch of the Woman's Auxiliary to the Board of Missions, was held yesterday in Grace Church, which was fairly filled, a majority of the audience being ladies.

The jury having been obtained, the trial of Mrs. Sarah Merrigan for the alleged murder of Miss Margaret Hamill, was continued yesterday in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge Tappan. District Attorney Winslow opened the case for the prosecution, giving a complete history of the crime.

LONDON, Oct. 27. The race for the Cambridgeshire Stakes, the principal event of the Newmarket Houghton meeting, took place to-day, and was won by Peut Etre, Chieftain coming in second, and Lord Gowran third. Out of 190 subscribers forty two horses started, with seven to one laid against Peut Etre, and sixty-six to one each against Chieftain and Lord Gowran.

The Episcopal Church Convention struck a blow at Ritualism yesterday by the adoption of the proposed amendment to canon 20, restricting ritualistic ceremonies. The debate was resumed at 11 o'clock, and was continued thereafter during the entire day. Dr. Shattuck, of Boston, protested against any restrictive measures being adopted.

The best representatives of Parisian intelligence, culture, wealth, and refinement were assembled at the Salle Ventadour last night, to hear Mme. Patti in the "Huguenots." For some days the city has been agitated over this unusual event. The celebrated cantatrice was to sing in French and take the part of Valentine for the first time in fourteen years.

The Tribune says that Benjamin A. Willis, who is the Democratic candidate for member of Congress against Isaac H. Bailey, "has not been specially prominent in politics, but he is a gentleman of untarnished reputation, a lawyer of good repute, and a soldier with an admirable record."

LONDON, Oct. 27.--The Mark Lane Express, in its weekly review of the breadstuffs market, says: "With less rain and colder temperature, the weather here and on the Continent has been favorable for late potatoes, seed-sowing, and all kinds of field work. In France potatoes are abundant, and they are free from disease. The tendency of the wheat market here is rather upward. In some cases there has been an ad....

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 27. The second annual meeting of the Southern Historical Society since its organization and removal to this city was held at the Capitol to-night, Gen. Jubal Early, President, in the chair. The hall was filled, many ladies being present, together with Gov. Kemper, Ex-Gov. Letcher, and other prominent men. Prayer was made by Rev. Dr. J.B. Jeler, of the Baptist Church.

Our readers will bear testimony that we have never been inclined to underestimate the importance of the Southern question, and that we have done our best to secure a candid and intelligent treatment of that question by the country. We have not regarded it from a partisan point of view, nor have we endeavored to make political capital out of it.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 27. The Courier-Journal's Shelbyville (Ky.) special to-night says that the young negro girl who was shot by masked men on Sunday morning last will probably recover. The affair has produced intense excitement in the county. The place where the outrage was committed is among the hills and is inhabited by a very rough population.

Campbell presided, and briefly stated the object of the gathering to ratify the Republican State, County, and District nominations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. The safe-burglary trial was continued to-day, and Zirruth, who is introduced by the Government as one of the conspirators, gave some testimony which, if sustained, must convict one or two of those indicted, and weigh very heavily against the rest of them.

Yesterday Ex-Judge John K. Porter, counsel for Mrs. Hardin, the alleged widow of Mr. George Hardin, began summing up the testimony in behalf of his client before Surrogate Hutchings. Mrs. Hardin, accompanied by a number of female friends, was present. During the course of the argument, Robert Walker, the alleged husband of the claimant, came into the court.
Yesterday the Park Commissioners met and decided to sell the east side lands at the auctionrooms No. 379 Fulton street on Dec. 1. The proceeds of the sale will be paid into the sinking fund.

Some of the Democratic stump speakers are claiming that their party has always been a consistent opponent of "rag money." In this latitude, it should be observed, these ingenious orators are discreetly silent on the general subject of finance. Only when forced to speak have they a word to say on this important matter.

Except in two or three Congressional districts the interest in the campaign by the voters, outside of the politicians' circle, is not great. The action at Worcester so dissatisfied many ordinarily active Republicans, and the nominations in several of the Congressional districts so disgusted many more, that all efforts to create an enthusiasm, or a show even of good spirits, by the orators and managers of the party, has signally failed.

The ladies were present in large numbers and occupied seats on the piazzas of the elegant club-house.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 28. The Republicans had a grand rally here this evening. There was a torchlight parade of mounted men, and a torchlight procession with displays of fireworks. Mechanics' Hall was crowded with an audience to hear speeches from Hons. J.G. Blaine and G.F. Hoar. Mr. Hoar spoke briefly, defending the Administration and the Republican Party against the attacks of their opponents.

Tilden wrote a letter to William Kent, arguing that Mr. Lincoln's election would be a sufficient cause for revolt by the Southern States, and declaring that the founders of our Government "left revolution organized, with power to snap the tie of confederation as a nation might break a treaty, and to repel coercion as a nation might repel invasion."

They were induced to take this step, it is said, by the Lieutenant of the "Guardia Civil," Don Pedro Davara.

The National Billiard Tournament was re sumed yesterday afternoon in presence of a numerous and interested audience. Ubassy and Daniels were the competitors in the first game, which was won by Ubassy in the twenty-fifth inning, making his average 12. Daniels only scored 104.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7.--The amount of national bank note currency received to-day at the Treasury for redemption was $1,197,900. This is the largest day's receipts since the organization of the agency. The agency, now being up with its work, will make returns as fast as the notes are received for redemption.

ATCHISON, Kan., Nov. 7.--The Daily Champion has official returns from twenty-seven counties, and reported majorities in twenty-six others. The majority for Osborne, Republican, in these counties is 10,342. The counties to hear from will increase this majority about 3,000 or 4,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. The Naval Examining and Retiring Boards resume their daily sessions at the Navy Department on Tuesday, the 10th inst. The subject of the grading and handling of grain, which has received so much attention on the part of the grain trade and railroad companies during the past year, has not yet been amicably settled. The schooner Manhattan, which arrived here last night, picked up in Lake Erie the crew of the schooner Nimrod, which was sunk by a collision with the bark Michigan, between Port Burwell and Port Stanley, on Saturday night. HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 11. Rufus Shipley, of Philadelphia, to-day made an application before the Governor and Board of Pardons for the appointment of a commission of experts to inquire into the sanity of Heidenblut, who murdered the German bakar in Philadelphia. The application is based upon a cummunication of Dr. Isaac Ray, of Philadelphia, who has grave doubts about the sanity of the prisoner. The application is hold under advisement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11.--There has been no little excitement here to-day, caused by an announcement published in New-York, that the President had changed his position respecting an increase of the currency. Nothing could be more absurd or unlikely than such a statement, and while no one here was found to believe it, many were excited because they supposed it was believed in New-York. The denial was promptly and spontaneously furnished to the press.

The Administration has received during the last few months some lessons that might, we should say, prove valuable touching the mischief that personal and political "organs" may easily do. WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. Treasurer Spinner has just made his fourteenth annual statement of the condition of the Treasury to the Secretary. It exhibits the transactions of the office in detail for the year ending June, 1874. A comparison of the tables of receipts with those of the year proceding shows a falling off from Customs of $24,985,689, and of $11,315,529 on account of internal revenue.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 14. A collision between the steamers Falcon and Louisiana occurred in Chesapeake Bay this morning about 1 o'clock. All the passengers of the Louisiana, with the baggage, express matter, and the mail were saved and brought to this port by the Falcon, which reached here at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The Louisiana was sunk.

Yesterday the building purchased by the Second Reformed Presbyterian Church, formerly worshipping in West Eleventh street, was formally opened. It is located in West Thirty-ninth street, near Seventh avenue, and was at one time a Jewish synagogue. WASHINGTON, NOV. 16--1 A. M.--Generally clear weather prevails in New-England, the Middle States, the lake region, and the Northwest, with variable winds and higher temperature east of Lake Michigan. Light rains are reported from the Ohio Valley, the Western Gulf States, and the South Atlantic Coast; the temperature has risen slightly in the Southern States, with easterly winds, and no decided change in pressure. WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. The latest attempt at revolution in Arkansas attracts little attention and causes little excitement here, for the reason, no doubt, that it happens after election. The Arkansas coups d'etat have been also too often repeated. Probably the Administration will not act immediately, if at all, further than may be necessary to proserve peace in the State.

In my last letter I spoke of the newly discovered peaks in the south-west, rivaling in height any yet found in the Rocky Mountains. Several were noticed over 15,000 feet high. This is in the Uncompahgre Mountains, and north of the Saquache range which marks the limits of the San Juan region, in the territory lately ceded by the Ute Indians. Their hostility heretofore has kept explorers away from that region.

The sale of what are known as the east-side park lands, which was advertised to take place on Dec. 1, has been postponed. Signor Verdi's "Manzoni" Mass is to be given at the Academy of Music, this evening. We shall be much surprised if the first recital this important work is to have in the United States does not attract an overflowing audience. No person interested in music can afford to miss to-night's performance.

HAVANA, Nov. 18. Official dispatches report the following incidents of the war: A small band of insurgents entered the vil- lage of Cano on the 9th inst., but was driven out by the garrison, with the loss of one killed and one taken prisoner.

The fight between Sheriff Conner and the City Marshals for the patronage of the Marine Court has now become a matter for the Supreme Court to decide upon. John H. Hillier, Marvin R. Clark, Louis Lubuscher, Thomas Sullivan, Daniel A. Murphy, and several others, appointed City Marshals by Mayor Havemeyer, at present divide the business of the Marine Court with the Sheriff's Office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. The trial of the alleged safe burglary conspirators was resumed to-day, Judge Humphreys said that, after consideration, he had decided to change his mind, and would hold a Court on Saturday. He thought when the Court adjourned yesterday he should not do so, but now he considered it more than probable there would be a session of the court to-morrow.

The chaotic Republic of Buenos Ayres is again in a great state of perturbation. The process of crystallization which had a partial development under the peaceful rule of Dr. Domingo Sarmiento during the past six years, is suddenly interrupted at the very beginning of the Presidential term of his amiable successor, Dr. Avellenada. The elements of cohesion have never been sufficiently strong to withstand the strain of a Presidential election.

The report of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue is of great importance to all who are studying the development of the country, or who are interested in the practical illustrations we present of the science of political economy. The taxes from internal sources sit very lightly on our people, and yet they yield the very respectable sum of one hundred and two millions of dollars, or more exactly $102,644,746.
Snow fell to the depth of five inches in various parts of Maine yesterday. The first snow of the season fell in NewHampshire and Boston yesterday.

There is war in Boston. Two formidable factions are rending the air with speeches and protests, and indignant and vociferous delegations to the City Hall render the life of the Aldermen and Street Commissioners of the "Hub" a burden.

PARIS, Nov. 20. M. Louis Blanc, who sits in the Assembly for the Department of the Seine, has issued a manifesto advising the union of all the Republicans in that body, instead of a coalition of the Centres, which he deems impossible.

A cable dispatch announces the death, in London yesterday, of Tom Hood, son of the late Thomas Hood, the well-known poet and author. The deceased was comparatively a young man, not having completed his fortieth year. He was born at Lake House, Wanstead, Essex, Jan. 19, 1835, and was educated at University College School, South Grammar School, and Pembroke College, Oxford.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. There is a good deal of excitement among the subordinate officers of the Treasury on account of the new method of treating their reports to the Secretary. They find a most surprising departure from routine, and in several intances their productions have been returned for emendation and change when they have overstepped the bounds of their duty and made recommendations not in harmony with the Secretary's views.

A report, calculated to annoy all the Tammany office-seekers, was circulated yesterday. It was rumored that Mayor Havemeyer had prepared charges against several heads of departments, with a view to having them removed by Gov. Dix. The Mayor, it was said, would select others, and thus prevent his successor, Mr. Wickham, from making capital for Tammany by appointing persons at the instance of Mr. John Kelly.

The financial question seems likely to be more prominent in Congress this Winter than last, and some of the leading politicians expect it to be the most important element in deciding the future of the Republican and Democratic Parties. The subject of the finances was in the first instance raised by the inflationists, and not by the hard-money party, who were the real conservatives on this question.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 10. In addition to the marine disasters by the storm of the 1st inst., before reported, the following are announced: Schooner Brigand, ashore; sloop Jane Nelson, leaking; sloop A.D.C., ashore; sloop Rose, ashore; the Manchester, ashore; the Defiance, ashore. The damage by the hurricane in Kingston is roughly estimated at 20,000.

The strike of the Tongshoremen yesterday developed nothing new, unless, indeed, the society men lost more ground, which seemed to be the case. Of the eleven species of grouse, known by a greater number of common names, only two are geneeral in Illinois, while a third was at one time generously distributed over the north-western counties of this State. Science has reduced the whole number of American grouse to six general, and the authorities on ornithology have so plainly classified them that no further confusion need occur as to what should be considered grouse.
The St. Stephen's Ladies' Fair will be continued this week.

An inquest, was held by Coroner Kessler yesterday in the case of Philip Woods, a cabman, of No. 317 East Thirteenth street, who died of heart disease while driving his cab. The malady was superinduced by excitement caused by a truck running into his cab. The jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the facts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. A delegation of nine Chiefs of the Turtle Mountain band of Chippewa Indians had an extended interview with the Commissioner of Indian Affairs to-day, in which they expressed the desire to cede the country now occupied by them, in Dakota, on the border of Manitoba, and go to the White-earth country, on the Missouri River, or elsewhere, provided they are prop erly recompensed.

Profs. Gannett, Peale, and party, constituting one of the divisions of Hayden's Explorations, have just returned to Denver from their season's work. The rain-fall experienced in the island during the last month has been unusually severe. NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 23. A court martial has been ordered by Gen. Emory for the trial of Lieut. Hodgson upon charges preferred by Gen. Morrow, who was sent to investigate Hodgson's actions and conduct in North Louisiana. It is understood the court will convene at Vienna Dec. 1. Gen. De Trobriand will be President, and Capt. Hon. Carl Schurz lectured last evening at Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, in connection with the Franklin Literary Institution. The subject of his discourse was "Educational Problems." The attendance was not, in point of numbers, at all in accord with the traditions of Plymouth Church, but the lecture was interesting and was received with manifest favor.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 23. Bishop Dame, who was recently arrested in Southern Utah, and confined at Beaver, is being brought to this city for safe keeping. He is charged with being connected with the Mountain Meadow Massacre.

On the 1st of August last a young married lady named Potter died at a water-cure establishment in West Twenty-second street. The evidence at the Coroner's inquest bore heavily against the proprietor of the water-cure, Christian J. Schiefferdecker, and the verdict of the jury asserted that the deceased came to her death through criminal negligence on his part.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 24. The official vote of New-Orleans Parish has been promulgated, and Gov. Kellogg has prepared the commissions for the newly-elected officials. The Returning Board has resolved to contiune the count by parishes in alphabetical order, beginning with Ascension Parish.

A large audience assembled last evening in Association Hall to listen to a lecture on the subject of "Metallic and Paper Currency," by Prof. Benamy Price, of Oxford University. Among the gentlemen on the platform were Messrs.

The first performance of "Lohengrin" this season will be given at the Academy of Music this evening. An excellent representation may be counted upon, and it is quite certain that the audience gathered to witness it will be exceedingly large. In addition to the entertainments already referred to as intended to occur this week, there is to be a special Thanksgiving night recital, to-morrow when "Il Barbiere" will be sung.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 24. At an early hour to-day people were pouring into the city by every sort of conveyance. Every railroad train from North, South, East and West Alabama was packed. Five infantry companies and one artillery company from Mobile, one infantry company each from Birmingham, Seima, and Montgomery, and a corps of cadets from the city school took part in the inauguration ceremonies.

The only change to be recorded in the sitution of the 'longshoremen's strike yesterday was the circumstance that the stevedore employed by the French Transatlantic Company went to work in the morning with a gang of society men, at the old rates.

The third session of the third Parliament since Hungary resumed sell-government was opened recently at Pesth, and our late German exchanges show that important affairs have already been in discussion before it.

A meeting of the importers of raisins and other foreign fruits was held at the office of the American Grocer, No. 141 Chambers street, yesterday afternoon. William H. Jackson called the meeting to order and nominated Mr. George G. Spencer Chairman, and as Vice Presidents, Messrs. D. D. Acker, H. K. Thurber, and W. R. Mitchell; Secretary, Joseph T. McDowell, who were duly elected.

Although not presenting anything especially striking, the Atlantic this month contains a series of uniformly entertaining papers. The space devoted to fiction is taken up by a further installment of Mr. W.D. Howells' "Foregone Conclusion," and a short story by Ajax T. Lamon "About a Barrel of Lard."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. The safe burglary trial was resumed to-day. Whitley, who has been absent since Friday, was in court. The room was unusually crowded, in anticipation of the continuation of the argument of Mr. Riddle.

A good deal of discussion is likely to arise over the interpretation of the two new sections of Article VIII, of the State Constitution, prohibiting the grant of State or local funds or property in aid of private undertakings.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. A few days ago a meeting of a portion of the pig iron trade was held at Allentown, in the Lehigh Valley, at which it was decided that the manufacturers engaged in that industry, should take summary action toward a material curtailment of production.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 24. The City Council to-day adopted the following:

TAHLEQUAH, INDIAN TERRITORY, Nov. 23-- via Fort Gibson.--A shooting affray occurred here this morning. Over forty shots werefi red and one man was fatally wounded and two others injured. The Council suspended business and all the stores were closed. Intense excitement prevails.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--The Joint Committee of Congress, to frame laws for the government of the District of Columbia, expect to be prepared to report shortly after the opening of the session. The general outlines of a scheme of government were practically decided upon early in the Summer, though the formal action of the committee, by which its work will be completed, has not yet been taken.

Notwithstanding the fact that the case of Sigismund Schwab was regarded by the delinquent liquor-dealers as a test, and that consequently the verdict rendered on it last Monday was calculated to fill their minds with great apprehension, the Excise Board merely look upon it as the sustaining of a law with the requirements of which the convicted dealer was or ought to have been familiar.

Everybody may see without much reflection that the two great questions on which public interest will be concentrated during the next few years--in fact, until they are satisfactorily settled--are those which turn upon the finances and the condition of the South.

TUSCUMBIA, Ala., Nov. 24. From reports received to-day it appears that the terrible wind storm which visited Tuscumbia on Sunday evening was also most disastrous in its effects upon the surrounding country. Houses were unroofed and fences blown down in every direction. Large trees were torn from the ground and carried many yards by the storm, crushing cabins and out-houses as they went.

The increase in tonnage of the United States in 1874 over 1873 is 239 vessels and 127,837 tons.

Since highway robbers came to the conclusion that it was not lowering their professional dignity to occasionally resort to the garrote system to prevent unnecessary exhibitions of feeling, the residents of many of the newer States have shown a desire to, so to speak, meet them half way.

The annual meeting of the Children's Aid Society was held at the Metropolitan National Bank yesterday, William A. Booth, President, in the chair, and C.L. Brace acting as Secretary. The minutes of the last annual meeting were read and approved. The annual reports of the Treasurer and Secretary were presented and referred to the Trustees, with power to publish such portions as they may think proper.

Two or three attempts have been made by the Hawaiians to negotiate a reciprocity treaty with the United States. Before the war the Southern sugar interest was strong enough to defeat any, such project, and the more recent reopenings of the subject have, for various reasons, met with no success.

The storm of Monday was severely felt in the Bay of Fundy. Several schooners at Digby were slightly injured.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. The safe burglary case has at last gone to the jury, who are this evening considering their verdict. The prospect of any agreement being reached this evening is very doubtful, though Judge Humphreys informed the jury he would be in readiness to receive their verdict as late as 10 o'clock.

There has been a dearth of news in this neighborhood since the date of my last letter, for, although the bombardment of Irun has continued, and is still taking place, yet the events of each day have been, to a great extent, of such a sameness that it is not an easy matter to give items of reliable intelligence.

LONDON, Nov. 25.--The great Midland Counties' Handicap was run to-day at the Warwickshire and Leamington Hunt meeting, which commenced yesterday. The race was won by Mr. Cartwright's Louise Victoria, who, at the Autumn meeting at Liverpool, carried off the Liverpool Cup from a field of twenty. Chance came in second and Lady Alice third.

Mr. FROUDE somewhere draws a parallel between the expenses at Oxford of the Earl of ESSEX and a modern brewer's or merchant's son. The nobleman of ELIZABETH'S time spent in a whole year only a fraction of what the man of the middle class of to-day lays out for the mere furnishing of his quarters.
Like most customs, the observance of our Thanksgiving festival has entirely changed its original character. In the nature of things, a practice loses its significance when it becomes a custom.

The applications by residents of the United States for space in the Chilian International Exposiclose this week. Dr. Stephen Rogers, Consul of Chili, in this City, and President of the New-York Commission for the Exposition, has already forwarded over sixty applications for representation, and from these it is evident that the United States will make a creditable show.

When the time came for the expedition to leave the North Park active search was made for a practicable trail. After some time the guides discovered what appeared to be one, but it soon proved to be nothing more than a game trail, which abruptly ended on the summit of the ridge.

CINCINNATI, O., Nov. 25. A Special dispatch from Indianapolis to-day, says: Between fifty and sixty gentleman met here to-day, to take measures to found a new national political party based upon a national currency platform. Horace H. Day, of Yew York, Alexander Campbell, of Illinois, Alexander Troup, of Connecticut, and L.A. Wood, of Kentucky, were among the most prominent men in attendance.

About this time last year England was feeling the recoil of our financial panic. The drain of gold to Germany and the United States had compelled the bank of England to run up the rate of discount to nine per cent., and fears of a grave commercial crisis mere pretty generally entertained.

Some of Prof. BONAMY PRICE'S definitions, given on Tuesday evening, were admirably clear and comprehensive. When he said that all currency was a tool for making exchanges he came very near the whole truth, so far as it has yet been untolded.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 25. The General Grand Chapter was called on at 9 A.M. to-day.

In the case of Max Strakoshch against the Police Commissioners, already noticed in THE TIMES, argument was had yesterday, in Supreme Court, Chambers, before Judge Donohue, on a motion for an injunction to restrain the defendants from intertering with or prohibiting Sunday concerts given by plaintiff in the Grand Opera-house.

The case of John F. Marshall and Charles Brunell, of the Broadway and Fourth Avenue Stage Line, charged by the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals with cruelly torturing a horse, was again resumed yesterday before Judge Sutherland, in the Court of General Sessions.

Not the least important of the amendments to the Constitution recently ratified by the people is section 10 of article 8. It takes away from the Legislature the power of voting money to sustain religious or charitable societies, or to aid any association, corporate or private.
The question whether a good Catholic can at the same time be a loyal subject is, of course, since the publication of Mr. Gladstone's pamphlet, the question which takes precedence of all others.

The American Cheap Transportation Association, which will meetin its second annual convention in this city on Tuesday, Dec. 1, is a very different organization from the New-York Cheap Transportation Association, the latter being local, with chief reference to transportation to, from, and in the City of New-York, while the former is national, having regard to the transportation of the whole Union and of adjacent countries.

The preparations which were being made everywhere throughout the City yesterday for the celebration of Thanksgiving Day were such as to give assurance that in every household, from the luxurious mansions of the more favored portion of the community to the humblest abodes of the artisan and laboring classes, the day will be one of mirth and festivity.

LONDON, Nov. 27, 5:30 A.M. A London director of the Bank of Buenos Ayres has received the following dispatch:

I succeeded in obtaining an interview with Count Belascom at Lastoula to-day, and he gave instructions to permit me to pass and return at Puncha whenever I desired to do so. After leaving Lastoula I once more ascended the rugged sides of the hill of St. Marcial, and upon reaching the summit found No. 1 battery busy at work firing upon Fort Mendivil.

There were some very good and timely suggestions in Mr. CARL SCHURZ'S lecture on "Educational Problems," of which we published the other day a full report. But in all that he said there was nothing truer, or that needed more to be said, than what he told his hearers about the source of our political evils. "We denounce," he said, "the prevalent corruption in high places.

The services at Trinity Church were of the usual attractive character, and were participated in by a large number of worshipers. The Thanksgiving sermon was preached by the Rector, Rev. Dr. Dix, who took his text from Acts xvii., 24; "God that made the world and all things therein is Lord of heaven and earth."

At the beginning of the Greeley campaign, this plan of "investigating" various departments of the Government was regarded as the surest means of winning a success.

Capt. McElwain, of the Twenty-first Precinct, has been for several days past engaged in investigating the circumstances surrounding the death of Lawrence Highland, which occurred on Sunday last at Bellevue Hospital, and yesterday succeeded in arresting David O'Brien and David O'Brien, Jr., father and son, residing at No. 148 East...

A case of more than ordinary interest has just been brought to a very unexpected termination in Newark, N.J. In April of the present year, several daring burglaries were committed in the shade of the Orange Mountains. The amount of property carried away was sufficiently large to excite the professional ardor of the principal detectives of the State. The result was the arrest of a person calling himself LOUIS WALRABE.
A Chinese mission school is to be estab- at Portland, Oregon, under the charge of Miss Mitchell.

With the exception of the Fourth of July, there is no day looked forward to with more eagerness by the juvenile members of the community than "Thanksgiving Day." Few of them, perhaps, have any idea of the origin of the anniversary, and fewer still of its real significance.

In the course of human events a minor son of E.H. Stewart, of Lewiston, felt himself a judge of horse-flesh and meeting Jeremiah Murphy in Lewiston, eracked his whip, and said he: "How will you swap horses?" Now Jeremiah Murphy had that sort of a beast in his barn whose possession impoverishes a man just in proportion as you in- crease their number.

The strike of the 'longshoremen begins to assume a threatening aspect, judging by the increased preparations on the part of the Police authorities in case any emergency should arise. The 'longshoremen appear to be rapidly awaking to the unpleasant fact that they have got the worst of the strike, and that the great steam-ship lines can get along without them.

The week began with two solemn days the feast of All Saints and the fast of All Souls. The Catholic Church has, in its sacred occasions, much to entice or impress the devout mind, and when reform has set aside some of its errors, the Protestant ought to be ready to join with the Catholic in using the helps offered by these sacred seasons for a common spiritual progress.

Inspector Speight, while on duty at the Central Office at 8 o'clock last evening, received a telegram from the Sixth Precinct, notifying him that a target company rejoicing in the very appropriate title of the "Original Hounds," composed of a gang of ruffians hailing from the western portion of the Eighth Ward, was marching through the streets of that precinct, headed by an carsplitting band, and acting in a very riotous and disorderly manner.

The night after Gen. Sheridan left the Cheyenne Agency a band of horse-thieves headed by the notorious desperado, Jack Dunnigan, invaded the place and succeeded in running off seventy-five head of fine Indian ponies belonging to the agency. Sheridan heard of the bold exploit the next morning, and sent orders to Fort Dodge to pursue the theives as soon as possible, and when found to "plant them on the prairie" without any further ado.

Rev. Henry Ward Beecher preached a sermon to his congregation yesterday morning in Plymouth Church. As usual, the church was thronged to its fullest capacity. The full strength of the choir was present, numbering eighty voices, and at 11 o'clock opened the services by singing an anthem from Zundell. After reading and prayer, the choir sang the "Thanksgiving Hymn," by Zundell.

It is full time for the warning which Dr. STEPHEN SMITH has just addressed, through the Board of Health, to the City authorities, in regard to opening sewers and making deep excavations in the thickly inhabited portions of the City.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 26. Arr., steamers Elizabeth, Clark, New-York; John S. Shriver, Wood, Philadelphia, S.d., brig Marie, Genea; schrs. Hattie N. Bangs, St. Pierre; J.M. Haskell, Trieste.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Thursday, Nov. 26, 1874. It is evident that a hard Winter is closing in upon the miners of this region. Probably not less than ten thousand men will be idle from November to March; and more than three-fourths of them go into this long suspension, at the beginning of the severest season of the year, entirely without money, and almost without credit.

A fishing company at Wainscot, in hauling their net in the surf off that place a few days ago, brought to the shore a rubber hip-boot containing the foot and ankle-bones of a human being. The bones were all in their natural position, although the flesh had been worn from them by the action of the water; and they were inclosed in a cotton stocking which was in a good state of preservation.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 26. The contests between the barge crews of the Schuylkill Navy today attracted a large number of persons, both banks of the Schuylkill River being occupied by spectators. The eight-car shell race between the two crews of the Undine Club started at 10 o'clock from Peter's Island, the course being to Turtle Rock, distance one and a half miles. WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. The jury in the safe burglary case has not yet given a verdict, and there is little reason to expect that they will reach any agreement. It is said that the vote stands ten not guilty, and two guilty. Whether there is any foundation for this rumor cannot be known.
NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 26. Thanksgiving services were held here in one church only, to-day, very few people observed the day, as requested by the proclamation.

The Memphis Appeal, for example, says: "Hayes, a Republican Congressman of Alabama, was a Confederate General. James L. Alcorn, Republican Senator from Mississippi, was a Confederate General. Charles Pelham, a Republican Congressman from Alabama, was a gallant Confederate.

Yesterday Rev. Dr. Bellows preached a sermon at All Souls' Church, corner of Fourth avenue and Twentieth street, on "The Duties of the Reopening Season of Home Life." His text was chosen from the thirty-sixth chapter of Jeremiah, twenty-third verse--" A fire on the hearth."

The troubles at the School of Medicine have been followed by the usual results, and the lectures have been suspended. The doors will remain closed until the 1st of December. This stops the preliminary examinations, as well as those for agreges and internes, and shuts the doors of the library and experiment rooms.

Mr. W.S. Andrews will lecture this evening at Parepa Hall. The first anniversary dinner and ball of the Arion Society will take place at Beethoven Hall on Monday evening next.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26. A very important case, in which the defendant was charged with being one of a firm of alleged forgers, who carried on their business at No. 48 New street, New-York City, was given a preliminary hearing here this afternoon, before United States Commissioners Smith and Biddle. The defendant was Mr. George F. Hilt, who occupies the position of Secretary of the Safeguard Insurance Company, of Philadelphia.

Union Thanksgiving services were held in various places on the island Jamaica, Newtown, Flushing, Huntington, Babylon, Riverhead, Greenport, Sag Harbor, and the day was generally observed as a holiday.

Frederick Nichols, of No. 34 East Ninth street, said to be an adroit and successful house and sneak thief, was arrested last evening by Detective Avery, of the Central Office, and is now locked up at Police Head-quarters. It appears that a servant girl in the employ of Ex-Judge Bosworth, residing at No. 415 West Twenty-second street who was about to leave her present employer, advertised for a situation.

I have carefully read in your issue of to-day your report of Dr. G. M. Beard's lecture on "Counterfeits of Science." The inference is strong that "Brown, the mind-reader," is one of the most formidable of these counterfeits, as a considerable portion of the lecture is devoted to him. What particular science Brown is a counterfeit of Dr. Beard fails to tell us.

Sheriff Lambson, by his whipping on Saturday, did not display that strict impartiality which should govern the dispenser of justice. With some he dealt quite mercifully; upon others he visited the pangs of a severe castigation. Still we are not going to sharply censure him for this.

After having been married some weeks, it came into the head of a young husband in this city, one Sunday, when he had but little to occupy his mind, to suggest to his wife that they should plainly and honestly state the faults that each had discovered in the other since they had been man and wife.
Ann and Mary McManus, of No. 35 Carroll street, were arrested yesterday morning on a charge of stealing $150 in jewelry and money from Alexander Varrel, of No. 73 Sackett street.

The announcement that Archbishop Bayley, of Baltimore, would officiate in St. Mary's Catholic Church, Jersey City, served to draw together yesterday morning an immense crowd of people in the church, corner of Second and Erie streets. A large number of priests were also present. The Archbishop appeared in respone to an invitation of the Young Men's Catholic Union, of Jersey City, and delivered a short address.

At 6:40 P.M. yesterday a fire occurred in the greenhouse of Charles Aiman, on Eighth avenue, near One Hundred and Thirty-first street, caused by the ignition of the framework from the ashpit. Damage, $1,000; no insurance.

LONDON, Nov. 26. The cutlers' annual banquet was given of Sheffield this evening. A large and distinguished company attended. Lord Houghton proposed the toast: "The United States, which, together with England, is engaged in the good work of preserving individual liberty."
The first natural ice of the season was formed last night at Chattanooga. The barge Dictator is ashore at Pigeon Bay, Lake Erie. Aid has gone to her from Detroit, Mich.

LONDON, Nov. 26. A deputation representing fifty-two Chambers of Commerce waited on Lords Derby and Carnarvon, the Foreign and Colonial Secretaries, to present objections to the proposed Canadian reciprocity treaty with the United States.

Frank McAuley and William Walker, hardy fishermen of Alcona, in the employ of James Craig, of Detroit, at 7 o'clock Tuesday morning set sail for their fishing-grounds. Their craft was the ordinary fishing boat the boat common to all the great lakes sharp at stem and stern, with a good keel and beam...

LONDON, Nov. 26. At last accounts, Mr. MacGahan, the Herald correspondent, was still imprisoned in San Sebastian. No further information has been received concerning his case. It is thought that the Carlists have cut the telegraph wires communicating with the town.

When they are noisy at all in Chicago, they are undoubtedly the noisiest people in the world; and they were unusually tumultuous a day or two since, when the case of a member of the Board of Trade, who was alleged to have been guilty of uncommercial conduct, came up for consideration.

A recent article in the Moscow Gazette gives an alarming account of the insecurity of life and property in Russia. Even in the most orderly and peaceful districts of the empire, says the writer, murders and robberies are becoming more and more frequent; and he attributes this chiefly to the defective arrangements for the discovery of crime and the capture and trial of criminals. Yesterday afternoon quite a number assembled at the Driving Park to witness two races, the first being between American Girl is harness, and the pacer Copperbottom under the saddle, for a purse of $2,500, mile heats, best two in three. The track was quite heavy, and, at first, the owner of American Girl refused to start.

If the wisdom of French politicians would only stretch half as far as their imagination, it would be well for their country. What they can do when they have a turn for rhetoric and trickery, is shown by the various aspects they have suggested in regard to the Septennate. When this word was coined to designate Marshal MACMAHON'S term of service, the unsophisticated mass of the people took it in its plainest sense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. The court-room was crowded to-day from 10 to 11 o'clock, in expectation that the jury in the safe burglary conspiracy would be sent for by Judge Humphreys. Harrington, Whitley, and Williams, the accused, were present. Counsel came in and took seats around the table. At 11:20 o'clock, Judge Hamphreys came in and took his seat.

"Lohengrin" was sung for the second time at the Academy of Music, last evening, in presence of an audience that filled the seats, aisles and standing-room generally of the spacious building. The assemblage, as represented by the returns of the box-office as well as gauged by the eye, was the largest gathered this season.

Coroner Woltman held an inquest yesterday in the case of the laborer, John Connerton, of No. 625 Washington street, who was killed in front of Gibbons' liquor store, No. 685 Washington street, by being struck on the head with a cart rung by George W. Murray, during a drunken brawl last Sunday morning.
George W. Leavitt, an insurance man, living near Gardiner. Me., hanged himself yesterday. A woman was killed at the Amesbury (Mass.) Mills on Thursday night by falling down stairs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--The jury in the safe burglary case were unable to agree, except as to Williams, whom they pronounced not guilty, and they have been discharged. It has been ascertained that in the case of Harrington the jury stood eight for acquittal and four for conviction, and in the case of Whitley, nine for acquittal and three for conviction.

A memorial tablet dedicated to Mrs. Bininger, one of the victims of the Ville du Havre disaster, has been placed in Grace Church, Whitestone.
Gen. S.W. Crawford, United States Army, is at the Glenham Hotel. Ex-Gov. John T. Hoffman is at the Clarendon Hotel.

There was a rumor yesterday that the Queen had suddenly fallen ill--an attack of apoplexy was supposed--and was in a dangerous condition. In the evening the Prince of Wales, who had been shooting over Mr. Villebois' estate in Norfolk, at a short distance from his own place at Sandringham, arrived suddenly in town instead of going home, and this was thought to give confirmation to the report.
The people of Stapleton had skating for one of their Thanksgiving Day enjoyments the first of the season. Yesterday the skating upon the flats was quite good.

BAISLEY At the residence of her son-in-law. G.W. Haight, Mamaroneck, N.Y., ELIZABETH, widow of the late. J.B. Baisley, in the 80th year of her age. The relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral services on Monday, Nov. 30, at the M.E. Church, at 10:30 o'clock. The remains will be taken to Westchester, St. Peter's Church. Train will leave Grand Central Detriot for Mamaroneck at 9 o'clock where carriages will be in waiting.

Coroner Kessler yesterday held an inquest in the case of the child Carrie Janisch, aged four years, whose death it was charged resulted from its having been put on a red hot stove and roasted to death, at No. 639 Washington street, by its mother. The mother, a portly German woman, was present in custody.

A visit to Wilton, N.H., reveals the fact that the people are very much disheartened over their losses by the recent fire, and all are undecided about rebuilding. Modern Japanese writers object to the use of the term "Oriental," as applied to their country. With much reason they argue that it is a geographical absurdity, for Americans especially, to speak of Japan as a part of the Oriental family. Yet, whatever may be true of the geographical classification of the country, Japan is purely Orien tal in its ethnological characteristics.

There was very little wind, so the ocean was quite smooth, and we held our course within two or three miles of the land.

PANAMA, Nov. 28. To-day is the fifty-third anniversary of the independence of the Isthmus, and is likely to be celebrated with more than usual enthusiasm. Five days, it is officially announced, are to be devoted to the festivities of the occasion, consisting of religions ceremonials, military displays, public processions, bull-fighting, horse-races, fireworks, and other spectacles. During these days business will be almost completely suspended.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Dec. 10.--All is quiet in the city and county. The county authorities have buried the bodies of fourteen negroes, and about the same number have been buried by private individuals. The white citizens still retain possession of the Court-house and jail, acting under the advice of the County Board of Supervisors, the members of which are negroes, with one exception.

Mr. WRIGHT, of Iowa, said on Monday he gave notice that he would call up a bill to abolish the Western Judicial District of Arkansas to-day, but after examining the rules he found that it could not be considered this week. He therefore gave notice that he would ask the Senate to take up the bill after the expiration of the morning hour on Tuesday next.

The House yesterday again yielded to the pressure of events and of popular opinion, and turned its attention to the financial question. This is a business which will be found much more profitable in a legitimate way, than introducing Mr. TOM SCOTT'S fingers into the Treasury by means of railroad subsidies, and we hope Congress will stick to the former and eschew the latter.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 10. A Vicksburg telegram to the Western Associated Press to-night says: The war is over and all is quiet. The Board of Supervisors to-day appointed a committee to bury the dead. The bodies of twenty-eight negroes have been interred, and many others are yet to be buried.

The Electoral law of Italy requires that the candidates voted for shall receive at least one-third of all the votes on the electoral list. A simple majority of all the votes cast does not suffice.

How to cope with diphtheria as an epidemic in cities is a question of intense public and general interest, and the profession should be ready with an answer. Judging from the protracted local continuance of the disease and its rate of mortality, diphtheria has reached a point in this City and vicinity that lifts it to the rank of an epidemic calling for special if not extraordinary efforts to suppress or "stamp out."

LONDON, Dec. 15.--The Times special dispatch from Berlin says Baron Holstein testified at Arnim's trial yesterday that in consequence of being informed by Fandsberg that Arnim mistakenly attributed to Bismarck the intention of going to war with France on account of the pastoral letters of the French Bishops, he wrote to a friend in Berlin to inform Bismarck that the Ambassador in Paris was becoming nervous at a critical period.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 15. A sudden cold term commenced along the Hudson yesterday, and the cold increased in intensity throughout last night. At 7 o'clock this morning the mercury in the thermometer marked zero, and for the first time this Winter ice was visible in the river opposite this city. From Rhinebeck to Albany the river is choked with heavy ice.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 15.--On the 14th of June last the dead body of one John Johnson was found in one of the streets of this city, with several gashes in the head, indicating that he had been brutally murdered. An investigation, lasting several weeks, failed to elicit any information as to the murderer, or even the place of the murder, further than that Johnson was not killed where found.

The bodies of the Bay Ridge burglars, Mosher and Douglass, still remain at the Morgue in Brooklyn, "where they will be retained," said Coroner Jones, stiffly, to a TIMES reporter, "until I get done with them. FALL RIVER, Mass., Feb. 8.--The Merchants' Mill continued operations to-day, although a very small number of operatives entered. To-night about 2,000 men, women and children gathered together, yelling and shouting, and a few blows were struck.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23.--The Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company several days ago sent a notification to the furnaces supplied by them to the effect that their stock at Port Richmond had become so depleted that it would shortly be exhausted. There is no way in which Mayor WICKHAM and his predecessor, Mr. VANCE, can so greatly serve the public as by a frank and full statement of the motives and expectations which do or did underlie the warfare upon the present Fire Commissioners. The history of this affair is brief, but significant.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24. The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad was held in this city to-day. The report of the Directors was read, after which the meeting adopted a new by-law making the number of Directors thirteen instead of twelve, as heretofore, and the election of Directors for the ensuing year being held, resulted in the election of the new ticket.

The Eleventh Ward Boys' Lodging-house, at the foot of East Eleventh street, has become of late years one of the most important and useful institutions of its kind in the City. It shelters nightly some sixty or seventy homeless boys, gathers the same number into a night-school held on the premises, and on Sabbath evenings every seat in its handsome chapel is occupied by the poor friendless boys of that quarter.
The colored students of Hampton College will, this evening, give a concert in the South Reformed Church, corner of Fifth avenue and Twentyfirst street.

The President sent to the Senate to-day the nomination of Harvey Jewell, of Massachusetts, to be a Judge of the Court of Commissioners of Alabama Claims, in place of Martin Ryerson, resigned. WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. The Senate today passed the bills for the admission of Colorado and New-Mexico, attaching to each ten or twelve amendments. Sebastien Erard, one of a large family, was born at Strasburg, April 5, 1752. His father, a cabinet-maker, was soon struck by his son's natural love for tools, and his great skill and delicacy in wood-work; but he had the wisdom to give him a thoroughly good education, and the boy took to drawing, mechanics, and geometry, with such ardor that he carried off all the prizes at school.

Information was received yesterday by Mr. Herman Geipcke, the agent in this City for the owners of the steamer Vicksburg, which was lost on Thursday night off Fire Island, that the vessel, though still standing above water, was fast going to pieces. Yesterday her masts were standing and the light remained burning at the mast-head as when she was abandoned.

It has been shown that the faculty of speech depends either wholly or mainly on the left side of the brain. A lesion in a particular region of this side produces the loss of the faculty of expresing ideas by spoken words. Out of more than a hundred cases of this peculiar disease--aphasia--only one is known (and that case is doubtful) in which the right side of the brain was diseased.

This lecture was one of the most eloquent of the course thus far. The series is to be concluded next week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--Mr. Pinchback is very angry on account of his failure to get a seat in the Senate, and has been using all his influence with the colored members of the Louisiana Legislature to prevent the adoption of any compromise.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Feb. 27.--A special dispatch to the Sioux City Journal, from Yankton, says Ephraim Witcher, a well-known citizen, who was a member of the expedition to the Black Hills, arrived in Yankton to-day. He reports having left his companions at the stockade of the expedition, within two miles of Harney's Peak, on Box Elder Creek, on the 3d inst.

It may be said that in Rome, at least, the Carnival has run completely out, and there is nothing of it left but the dregs. A more shallow and trivial display than that of the present year has hardly ever before been known. Two more days of it are left, and then the final whisk will be given for this season, and perhaps forever in this Rome, to its shabby tail.

The City of Baltimore has lately been the object of a great deal of interest among business men in New-York and elsewhere. Baltimore is, with the exception of Washington and Alexandria, the nearest seaport, in a direct line, to Chicago. As compared with New-York, the difference is a hundred miles, the distances, in an air line, being respectively about 610 and 710 miles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--An effort will be made in the House to-morrow morning to set aside the Appropriation bill, and carry out the scheme which was concocted two days ago to take up the Arkansas report, and substitute for the resolution of the majority that which was submitted by Mr. Ward.

Culyer, the Chief Engineer of Prospect Park, Brooklyn, proposes a plan for preventing the freezing of street hydrants, the main features or which are, that they shall be placed below the surface of the sidewalk and be inclosed by either a brick chamber or cast-iron cylinder, so that they can be easily gotten at.

The University Place Presbyterian Church, corner of University Place and Tenth street, was organized by the Presbytery of New-York on the 26th of September, 1870, by the union of the church of that name and the old Mercer Street Presbyterian Church, now occupied by the congregation of Dr. Deems.

This place is stricken with a panic caused by a threatening ice gorge that has formed in the Delaware River since 11 o'clock this forenoon. The river here is about 600 feet wide, the banks rising twenty-five feet above the stream. It is spanned by a wire suspension bridge from the foot of Pike street.

This evening's session of the Legislature was brief and uneventful in both Houses. Not one-half of the Senators were present, and nothing was done by them which calls for remark. In the Assembly there was a fair attendance, but the proceedings were devoid of interest except for the introduction of several bills.

The Democrats to-day elected Roswell M. Richardson Mayor by a majority of 436, against a Republican majority last year of 507. They also elect a Municipal Judge, and have large gains for Councilmen and Aldermen.

Mr. Henry Bergh, President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, accompanied by his counsel, Mr. Elbridge T. Gerry, appeared in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, to answer before Recorder Hackett for alleged contempt of court in having addressed to the last Grand Jury a communication reflecting on the action of that body in the case of Jefferson Carpenter, charged with dog-fighting in a Rivington street basement.
Mme. Ristori will this evening enter upon the fulfillment of her engagement at the Lyceum Theatre. She has elected to reappear in "Elizabeth," Giacommetti's well-known tragedy.

Tracy closed his opening address to the jury yesterday afternoon, and to-day the evidence for the defense will, in all probability, be introduced by Mr. Beecher taking the witness stand in his own behalf. The court room was crowded to repletion. Mr. and Mrs. Beecher and their sons occupied their usual seats. Mrs. Tilton was absent, owing to the illness of her son Ralph, who, however, is in a fair way toward recovery.

Mr. WILLIAMS, of Michigan, from the Committee on the Pacific Railroads, reported a bill specifying in great detail the points in regard to which the Pacific Railroad companies are required to make returns to the Government of the receipts of traffic rates, which was passed.

The political campaign in Connecticut is now fairly under way, and very soon both parties will enter into the heat of the contest. State tickets have been in the field some time, and by the close of the present week the Congressional nominations will be completed.
Gov. Booth, of California, started from San Francisco, for the East, on Sunday.

The annual meeting of the Board of Managers of the Nursery and Child's Hospital was held at the institution in Fifty-first street yesterday. Rev. Dr. Potter presided, and Mrs. T.H. Craven acted as Secretary. After a prayer by Dr. Potter and the singing of a carol by some of the female inmates of the institution, the regular order of business was taken up and the reports of the officers were read and approved.

Dr. William Adams, Rev. C.A. Stoddard, D.D., Rev. Iren us Prime, and several of the members of the College Faculty. Trains on the east ern roads leading into Chicago arrived from three to six hours late this morning on account of the snow. There is a heavy snow-storm prevailing in this part of the country, and it is probable that there will be a general blockade on the railroads.

The Hudson River tunnel, upon which work has already been commenced at the foot of Fifteenth street, Jersey City, is one of the largest en terprises undertaken in this vicinity of late years. The idea was first suggested to a party of Californians who were delayed at the Jersey City ferry one foggy day in March, 1873, by obstacles offered by the fog to navigation.

The VICE PRESIDENT laid before the Senate the credentials of Hon. Isaac P. Christiancy, United States Senator from the State of Michigan for the period of six years from March 4, 1875. They were read and placed on file.

The Civil Rights bill has been signed by the President. The "Force bill," after passing the House by a vote of 135 to 114, is now before the Senate. We reprint it today, and it ought not to need much persuasion from us to induce our readers to study it.

I cannot find words to express the glory of these latitudes. We are sailing to-day over a sea that is like an inland lake, just dimpled with the wandering airs. The ship glides along with a gentle roll that is like the rocking of a cradle. Flying-fish rise up and skim away under a sky with scarcely a cloud, and yet so cool are we that I have made scarcely a change in my clothing.

The pressure has increased over the North-west and upper lakes, thence to Missouri and Kentucky, with colder weather and North-west winds. Southerly winds, warmer, cloudy, and rainy weather prevail in the Southern States. North-easterly and north-westerly winds falling barometer, cloudy and rainy weather over the lower lakes, the Middle, and Eastern States, with higher temperature, except in the latter. The rivers have risen at St. Louis, Memphis, Cincinnati, and Louisville, and fallen at Pittsburg.

Joseph Stuppe, alias Carl Vogt, who has been in Ludlow Street Jail about three years, pending the result of efforts to have him extradited, on the charges of arson and murder, was held yesterday by Commissioner White to await the issuance of a warrant of extradition by President Grant.

In the House of Commons this evening, Sir M.H. Beach, Chief Secretary for Ireland, introduced a bill lessening the penalties for the unlawful possession of arms in Ireland, repealing the law which authorizes the closing of public houses and the arrest of persons found outdoors at night in the proclaimed districts, and removing the restrictions on newspapers.
A special dis patch to the Gazette from Fort Wayne says a sleetstorm prevailed there all night and to-day, detaining railroad trains considerably.

The Sundry Civil Appropriation bill was finished in Committee of the Whole a little after 2 A.M. to-day, and the committee rose and reported it to the House.
In the Senate, 1 A. M. Mr. Sargent, of California, from the Committee on Appropriations, reported the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill, with amendments, and it was placed on the calendar.

Young, of Dartmouth College, one of the American astronomers engaged in observing, at Pekin, the late transit of Venus, to give some incidents connected with the observations there made.

The third con ference on the difference existing between the two Houses on the Legislative Appropriation bill has been unable to agree and a fourth conference was ordered. The House is determined to adhere to its position in reference to fixing salaries of their own Clerks, and will yield only when it becomes necessary to do so in order to save the bill.

At the city election to-day, Samuel B. Stevens, Democrat, was elected Mayor by 669 majority. The Democrats elect four of the five ward officers. The Common Council will stand ten Democrats to seven Republicans. Poncher, Democrat, was elected Mayor of Oswego by about 200 majority. The Republicans elect five of the eight Aldermen. The election at Ithaca resulted in a great falling off in the Democratic majority of last year.

To-day, in the Marine Court, will begin the trial of one of the most extraordinary breach-ofpromise suits on record. The damages are laid at the modest amount of $50,000. The fair complainant, Miss May Chamberlayne, was sixteen years old on Sunday last, yet she is five feet eight inches in height, and a fully-developed woman.
B.P. Cheney, of Boston, is at the Brovoort House.
The House to- day, by a unanimous vote, directed the resolution of censure passed in 1862 upon Simon Cameron for alleged official misconduct while Secretary of War to be rescinded.

Mr. Barnum was renominated for Congress in the Fourth District today, though not with the same unanimity that has characterized the previous conventions, as out of 108 votes there were forty-six against him, all from Fairfield County. The convention did a neat thing in unconsciously recognizing Mr. Barnum's almost uniform absence from his seat, by recommending the name of Barnum for a Representative in Congress.

The Aldermanic Committee on Law met yesterday afternoon, Alderman Purroy in the chair, and the investigation of the official conduct of Controller Green was continued. Ex-Mayor A. Oakey Hall was the first witness called. In reply to a question concerning the refusal of the Controller to pay just claims against the City, he said that he had been counsel in some fifty suits, in which the costs had amounted to about $2,000.
City Physician Marsh reports 158 deaths in Paterson last month.
The Sundry Civil Appropriation bill was received from the House of Representatives and referred to the Committee on Appropriations.

W. Van Rensselaer, Corresponding Secretary; Edith G. Putnam, Secretary, and John Crosby Brown, Treasurer.

The New-Jersey Midland Railway Company being unable to pay its coupons, the Chancellor of New-Jersey has granted an order, at the instance of some of the bondholders, to show cause why the road should not be placed in the hands of a receiver. PANAMA, Feb. 21.--Tranquillity prevails in the State of Panama. Her Britannic Majesty's ship Dryad, which came from Jamaica to inquire into the the courage committed on Dr. Piggot, in English subject, has returned to Jamaica. The case, with the claim thereon, has been sent to Bogota.

ALBANY, March 9. Stevens, the contumacious witness, was arraigned before the bar of the House to-night. The proceedings, it must be confessed, were not likely to increase his respect for the body for which he is said to have expressed contempt. Shortly after the House was called to order the Speaker called on the Sergeant at Arms, and that officer at once presented himself at the bar, having Mr. Stevens in custody.
Vice President Henry Wilson is at the Grand Central Hotel. Judge Amasa J. Parker and Chancellor John V.L. Pruyn, of Albany, are at the Brevoort House.

E.J. Quirk, a contractor, while under the influence of liquor, attempted to enter the private office of Controller Green. He was met by Mr. Devlin, the door-keeper, who, upon observing the condition of his guest, refused to permit him to enter, but courteously engaged to deliver any message that the contractor might wish to send him.
