Previous to the passage of the Police Court bill in 1873, there was no legal provision made for the keeping of accurate statistics of crime in this City. One of the chief arguments by which the bill was supported by Mr. DORMAN B. EATON and others, was that it would fully supply this defect.

A very fair indication of the condition of the Democratic Party, and of the motives which influence its managers, is afforded by the character of the United States Senators recently elected, and who have just taken their seats at Washington. The most noticeable feature in the new group of Senatorsis the presence of several ex-Confederate Generals and officers.

HAVANA, March 9. Captain General Valmaseda has issued a proclamation, in which he says additional reinforcements will soon arrive from Spain, and with the aid of the people, under the battle cry of "Spain, Religion, and the King," Cuba will be saved. He proposes to have the revenues of the Government honestly applied, and the soldiers well and justly treated.

The inquest in the case of the late Jacob B. Stockvis was continued before Coroner Kessler yesterday afternoon. Dr. Hirsch, Mrs. Hirsch, and daughters were present. Coroner Kessler, before calling the first witness, explained to the jury the different forms of commitment used in the Police Courts.
M. Barthlemi Laurent's grand vocal and instrumental concert will take place on the 19th inst. at Steinway Hall.
The new Sixteenth Ward fire-bell has been tested by the Fire Commissioners and found satisfactory.

The first really bold example of legislative jockeying that has come up during the present session was developed to-day in the Assembly on the passage of one of the three bills now before the Legislature designed to transfer the process patronage of the Marine Court to Sheriff Conner. The House was occupied all day with third readings of bills, and this one happened to come up last, and so prolonged the session until 2:50 o'clock.
The Constantinople papers speak of a work in four volumes, published recently in French, by Gregoire Aristarchi Bey, Turkish Minister at Washington, upon Ottoman legislation.
Rev. Thomas Nicholls, of Long Island, has been elected to the pastorate of the First Presbyterian Church, in New-Brunswick.

When the doors of the Aldermanic Chamber were opened yesterday, a large concourse of laborers rushed in and filled every part of the gallery. They had come upon a fruitless mission, because they expected that the City Fathers would take steps to have them employed on various public improvements. The latter, however, have no patronage at their disposal, but, for obvious reasons, they are too timid to announce the fact.

Judge Neilson regretted the illness of Mr. Fullerton, and hoped it would be but temporary.

Mr. Gladstone has published under the title of Vaticanism the title is a good hit in tself his answer to the remonstrances and reproofs provoked by his former pamphlet. It is in every way much superior to the Expostulation, more elevated in style, larger and clearer in thought, and closer and more decisive in argument; yet it has for the present fallen rather flat.

The Panama Railroad Directors met yesterday in the Pacific Mail Steam-ship Company's building, and listened to a verbal report from Mr. Trenor W. Park, who recently passed over the road on a tour of investigation. Mr. Park found everything in a very satisfactory condition.

WASHINGTON, March 11. The following is Secretary Bristow's call for bonds in detail. They are under the act of Feb. 25, 1862. The coupon bonds are of the fourth series: Coupon Bonds $50. No. 10,001 to No. 15,400, both inclusive; $100, No. 27,501 to No. 40,000, both inclusive: $500, No. 13,601 to No. 20,000, both inclusive; $1,000, No. 33,000 to No. 66,000, both inclusive. Total, $4,063,750.

WASHINGTON, March 11. Rear Admiral Collins, commanding the United States naval fores on the South Pacific stations, reports to the Navy Department, under date of Talcahuana Chili, Feb. 7, that he would remain in that port for some weeks for necessary repairs on the flag-ship Richmond and her boilers, exercising the crew, and getting the vessel ready for sea. The Omaha had been ordered to Talcahuana from Valparaiso, for exercise and general inspection.

CONCORD, N.H., March 11 Midnight. The Republicans claim that the Senate stands five Democrats and five Republicans, with no choice in Districts Two and Four. The Democrats claim to have elected a Senator in the Second District, giving them six Senators to five Republicans.

By a prompt and proper decision in the case of the Fire Commissioners Gov. TILDEN can do more than by any other official act to establish his administration in public confidence. It is, of course, necessary that the Governor should take all the time that may be required to make himself acquainted with the facts of the case, but we do not believe that he will allow any political considerations to delay his decision.

The case in which the will of Eliza Baker is contested was continued in the Surrogate's Court, yesterday, and, after cumulative testimony had been given for the contesting relatives, an adjournment was taken to next Thursday morning.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 11, The National Convention of Grangers and Labor Reformers, to complete the organization of a new party, under the greenback system, assembled in this city at Halle's hall to-day. It was a mass convention, and fifty-five delegates were present from twelve. States, the majority being from Indiana, Ohio, Illinois, and Missouri.

A correspondent from New-Jersey inquired recently, as to the duty of villages and small towns in regard to the execution of the law for universal education. This writer stated that in his own village and in many others, there are no "night-schools," or "industrial schools" for the truant and semi-vagrant class of children, and that if such children were arrested the authorities would not know what to do with them.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 12. The Greenback Convention reassembled in Halle's Hall at 10 o'clock this morning, Mr. Hooton presiding. The Committee on Resolutions was not yet, fully prepared to report a platform, and the Chairman stated that there was a difference of opinion among the persons on that committee as to the number of members the National Central Committee should consist of.

WASHINGTON, March 12. The Senate today resumed the consideration of the resolution for the admission of Pinchback, and devoted about three hours to the discussion. Senator McCreery spoke less than an hour.

HAVANA, March 12. Captain General Valma seda, soon after his arrival, called together a number of the wealthiest citizens, and requested them to advance a loan of 100,000 sterling, to pay the expense of bringing reinforcements from Spain. The sum required was immediately subscribed.

Information was received in Jersey City last evening that John H.F. Hannon, who was arrested in Jersey City some time ago on a charge of having embezzled $2,000 in money from the Southern Coast Steam-ship Company of San Francisco has just been sentenced to imprisonment in the California State Prison for three years.

A private library containing many choice standard and illustrated works will be disposed of by Messrs. Leavitt, at their Clinton Hall Sales-rooms, on Monday and Tuesday evenings next. Among the authors represented are Humboldt, Froude, Hawthorne, Hazlitt, Pepys, Stanley, Swinburne, Thackeray, Dickens, and numerous others.

As was briefly stated in THE TIMES of yesterday, the Tammany leaders have agreed upon a plan for the division of the patronage at the disposal of ex-Gen. Fitz John Porter, the New-Jersey Commissioner of Public Works in New-York City.

The Aldermanic Committee on Law met again yesterday to resume their investigation of the management of the Finance Department. The audience was mainly composed of persons who had claims against the City.

The brief installment of the names of Referees appointed through the influence of Mr. John Kelly, the Tammany Chief, which was published in THE TIMES a few days ago, is merely representative. An exhaustive list would till several columns.

Certain of the witnesses in the great trial now going on have put in the plea, in misericordiam, that they were "not accus- tomed to the witness-stand." They would seem to imply that being a witness was a kind of vocation in life, or if not a vocation a lot; something which needed study, preparation, and, above all, practice, for the proper discharge of the duties which it imposed.
It is rumored that Col. Sterry, of the Sixth Regiment has tendered his resignation.

On application of counsel for William M. Tweed, Judge Donohue yesterday granted a writ of error in favor of the prisoner. The appeal under the writ is from the decision of the General Term of the Supreme Court sustaining the decision of the Judge at Chambers refusing to discharge Tweed on writ of habeas corpus.

The engineers who are operating on the ice with nitro-glycerine to-day struck a ridge of ice some distance below the high wall that holds the miles of ice above. Drilling through it, the ridge was found to be twelve feet thick, very solid, and lying on the bottom of the river.
THE "DISTINGUISHED VISITOR" CLUB.

The turf season of 1875 bids fair to out- rival all its predecessors in brilliancy, and preparations have already commenced to set the ball in motion. The Secretaries of the several associations are preparing their programmes, and their promulgation will shortly excite the attention and enthusiasm of the sportsmen.

The burglar with whom I held pleasant and instructive converse for several hours, as heretofore narrated, did not by any means diminish my appetite for further and even more intimate acquaintance with other kinds of outlaws. Therefore, I cast about for a "sneak," and with the aid of my friend, the ex-detective, finally found what I wanted.

"As great a beauty of a rose as ever I seen in my born days!" said old Peter Lally, straightening his bent back, and gazing tenderly at the exquisite bloom which was the product of his skill. "To think that the likes of it must ever and always be sold to the stranger, and never a master or mistress at Hildebrand Towers to take pride out o' it!"

The new Methodist Episcopal Church in Sixty-first street, between Second and Third avenues, will be formally dedicated to-day at 10:30 A.M. The edifice, including a lecture-room and parsonage, occupies a plot of ground 130 feet long by 100 feet in width and is built of brick and stone, in the Gothic style of architecture of the fourteenth century.
The arrests by the Police last week numbered 1,666.

PARIS, March 13. The Marquis de Clernont-Tonnerre, formerly second Secretary of the French Legation at Washington, but now First Secretary of the Legation at St. Petersburg, has received the cross of Chevalier of the Legion of Honor.

An examination in the case of Andrus Montfort, charged with threatening to burn the outbuildings of Supervisor Gubner, of the town of New-Utrecht, was held at Fort Hamilton, yesterday, before Justice C.W. Church.

CORK. March 13. There was considerable disorder in the town of Tipperary last night because of the refusal of some of the residents to illuminate their dwellings in honor of the second election of John Mitchel to Parliament. Several houses which were not illuminated were attacked by a mob and sacked. The town is quiet now.

The disposition to "get even" with railroad companies, as the hard-shell Baptist clergyman would say, is "powerful strong" this year. First of all it was manifested by the Democratic legislators who were restricted in their free riding powers.

CHARLES LAMB declared that if he had been the father of a son, he would have brought the boy up to "the life contemplative," and had the scion devoted to such a career only been worthy of the stock, men might have looked for some very queer, quaint, and intelligent reflections.

The business transacted during the past week has been of an uneventful character, nearly all the sales effected having been under legal orders, and the property sold of comparatively little value, the auction in no instance calling for special notice. No sales at private contract have been reported, and the market has been generally quiet.

A few days ago the journals published a letter from Paul Feval respecting the treatment he had received in New-York or that his play had received but as it was taken from a New-York journal I paid were little attention to it. I remember that I was amused at the moment about the description of Harry Palmer, who was, in Paul Feval's eyes, small, dumpy, and extremely well dressed.

The trout-fishing season, as all true sportsmen know, commences to-day, and will keep open until the 15th day of September next. Perhaps no branch of out-door amusement is more generally indulged in, or gives greater pleasure to its legion of admirers, than trout fishing. The number of prisoners in the Kings County Penitentiary on Saturday, was 627.
Patrick Tracy, aged fifty-eight, died suddenly yesterday at his residence. No. 432 Pearl street.

The number of gentlemen who were members of the last Congress, and who were not elected to the next, is very large. During the Administration of President LINCOLN a Senator from a Western State called at the White House to present his successor, who was to take his place in the Senate Chamber within a few days.

The Church of the Messiah, Park avenue and Thirty-fourth street, has for many years held a leading place among the Unitarian churches of NewYork. That this prominence has been deserved will be conceded by all who are in any degree acquainted with the work and reputation of the church since its foundation. The naphtha experiments on the ice gorge at this place were to-day tried by Mr. Cheesebrough, who so generously donated twenty-five barrels of that combustible for the purpose. Up to the trial he was sanguine of its success, but the first attempt proved that the idea of burning a channel through the ice was entirely futile.

"It is a long lane," says the proverb, "that has no turning." We may fairly hope that the proverb holds true with reference to the tedious course of dull business through which the country has been passing since the early Autumn of 1873, and that the many signs of better times which were noticeable last week will not fail of fulfillment.

John Hoff, a prominent banker of Reading, Penn., died yesterday, aged seventy years.

John W. Longyear, for nearly five years past Judge of the District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, and, by virtue of his office, acting as United States Circuit Judge, died very suddenly at his residence in Detroit, on Wednesday night, the 10th inst., at 11:15 o'clock, of indigestion, the disease affecting the heart. Judge Longyear was born in Shandaken, Ulster County, N.Y., Oct. 22, ...

The fiftieth annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design will open on Thursday, April 8, and close on Saturday, May 29. This is a somewhat briefer period than usual for the galleries to remain open. Works for exhibition will be received from Thursday, 18th inst., until Wednesday, 24th inst., after which date none will be admitted. Tuesday, April 6, will be "varnishing day."

BRIGHAM YOUNG'S case before Judge McKEAN is a peculiar one. In fact, the original decision against the Prophet and in favor of ANN ELIZA, the nineteenth wife, was peculiar. This is all owing to the fact that Mormon marriage is an anomalous institution. The plea of BRIGHAM YOUNG, in answer to ANN ELIZA'S suit for divorce, was that she was not his lawful wife.

Gen. Fitz John Porter has come to the surface again. The Democrats have had an opportunity to reward him, and they have not hesitated to do so. They have made him Commissioner of Public Works in that Democratic paradise known as NewYork City. Fitz deserves this recognition at their hands. We like this trait of gratitude which pervades the breast of the average Democrat.

Michigan holds its biennial Spring election on the 5th of April, choosing at that time two Associate Justices of the Supreme Court and two Regents of the University in the State at large, the Judges of the twenty Circuit Courts, of the State by districts, Superintendents of Schools in all the thoroughly organized counties, and a full complement of township officers. The trial of Capt. Thomas Killalea, of the Eleventh Precinct, was continued yesterday before the Board of Police. The trial was adjourned last Monday for the purpose of procuring the testimony of the Kasefangs, who were not present on that day. On Wednesday last Col. Fellows, of counsel for the accused, was notified that the board had decided not to call the witnesses named.

WASHINGTON, March 15. It is the determination of the Government to secure to the Sioux Indians all their treaty rights with reference to the Black Hills country, and therefore all persons will be prohibited from going there, and those now there will be required to remove until the Indian title is extinguished. The Government will endeavor to extinguish the Indian title at the earliest practicable moment.

A few hours before the last Congress went out of existence, the Eads Jetty bill for the improvement of the mouth of the Mississippi River was tacked on to the general bill appropriating moneys for the improvement of rivers and harbors, and with it became a law. There seems to be no doubt that Congress, in taking this very hasty action upon a most important matter, was actuated by the best of motives.

The Board of Directors of the New-York Bridge Company held their regular fortnightly meeting at No. 21 Water street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, Hon. Henry C. Murphy, the President, in the chair. The Directors present were Mayor Hunter, Controller Powell, and Messrs. Aspin wall, Carroll, Stone, Stranahan, Marshall, Nichols, Booth, Motley, Riley, and Thurber.

John Kuppel, of No. 237 East Fifth street, was brought before Justice Bixby at Essex Market Police Court yesterday, charged with keeping a lottery shop at the above number. He was held in $1,000 bail to answer.

WASHINGTON, March 15. The Secretary of State to-day communicated to the Senate, in accordance with a resolution of that body, the correspondence between the United States and the Spanish Government in relation to the claim for indemnity from Spain for the execution at Santiago de cuba of Americans who were on board the Virginius.

The various publishing houses in this City feel deeply aggrieved by the passage of the new Postal law, which increases the rates on third-class mail matter to one cent per ounce. It is clearly understood by them that the bill was hurried through at the last moment, in the interest of the express companies, and that it does not in any sense embody the views of the members of either House.

Senator Ferry of Connecticut, addressed the Senate briefly to- day on the Pinchback resolution, confining himself to replying to the theory of Senator Morton touching the binding force of the executive recognition given Kellogg. Three more of the recently-removed Customhouse Inspectors have been reinstated. They are Messrs. Chamberlain, Davidson, Robertson.

ALBANY, March 15. Both houses of the Legislature sat for about two hours this evening, with a fair attendance of members for a Monday evening in each of them, and yet but little interesting or important business was transacted.

A cold north-east rain-storm has prevailed here since noon to-day, but the fall has been light, and the indications are that the weather will clear before morning. At the special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, Mr. Samuel B. Ruggles, from the Committee on Canal Legislation, sought to have the rules suspended to permit him to present the committee's report. He urged the necessity of haste, as the question of canals was to come before the Legislature for action this week, and it was advisable to have the report before that body previous to their action.

The Commissioners of Emigration recently received a communication from the Legislature calling upon them for answers to seventeen questions touching the stewardship of the board since its reorganization in 1873. The Secretary, Mr. Jackson, has been busily at work during the past two weeks preparing detailed statements covering the information asked for.

The sixth annual report of the Massachusetts Bureau of Labor Statistics, which has just been completed and presented to the Legislature, is an exhaustive document of over 600 pages, and contains some valuable information on all questions affecting the welfare of the working classes. OTTAWA, March 15. His Excellency, the Governor, General, will shortly leave for Europe, to be absent about three months. The Government will be administered during his absence by Lieut, Gen. William O'Grady Haly, C.B., commanding her Majestry's forces at Halifax.

We may now feel tolerably sure that the once threatening Virginius question has finally been set at rest. We published yesterday morning a full statement of the agreement between this country and Spain, by which all points remaining in dispute previous to that agreement are definitively settled.

Last evening Capt. Gunner, of the Eighteenth Precinct, received information from Dr. Robert A. Barry, of No. 233 East Thirteenth street, to the effect that Mrs. Annie J. Curtis, aged twentyeight, residing at No. 12 Union square, was lying at the point of death from the effects of criminal malpractice. The Captain at once proceeded to the house, where he found Mrs. Curtis sinking rapidly.

Notwithstanding the rain-storm of yesterday and last night, the Delaware River shows very little change. The water is gradually rising, which is greatly in favor of a quiet breaking up. No one can tell, however, how soon the upper streams may begin to pour their annual freshots into the river, and cause the flood that now alone is dreaded.

As foreshadowed in THE TIMES of Monday, the Saratoga compact, so far as the freight tariff is concerned, has been abandoned. This morning the three trunk lines composing the combination will publish their new schedule, which, as will be seen below, is a return to the old rates that existed at the time the compact was made.

The inquest was continued yesterday in the case of Jacob B. Stockvis, the blacking peddler, whose death, it is claimed by his relatives, resulted from injuries received after he had been arrested on a charge of intoxication. Prof. Asa Hall, United States Navy, has been ordered to duty at the Naval Observatory.

ALBANY, N. Y. March 16. The General Savings Bank bill, as framed in and reported from the Committee on Banks, was under consideration in Committee of the Whole in the Assembly to-night. An amendment offered by Mr. Alvord, providing that no salaried officer of any savings bank shall be a trustee thereof, was adopted. The committee finally progressed the bill, and it was made the special order of business for Thursday evening.

There is a balance in the City Treasury of $1,265,310.40, deposited in twelve city banks. It is calculated that there are buildings valued in the aggregate at $60,000 already in course of erection in the Eastern District this Spring.

PARIS, March 16. L' Univers publishes the text of an address, which, it says, Gen. Cabrera has issued to the Carlists, and which he will immediately dispatch from Paris. In this paper Gen. Cabrera announces his recognition of Alfonso as King of Spain. He points to the country's need of peace, and appeals to the patriotism of the Carlists to discontinue a struggle hopeless from causes which he refrains from revealing.

The Detroit and Milwaukee Railway were compelled to default the interest on the November, 1813, and May and November, 1874, coupons owing to depreciation of their equipment and decrease of earnings, the result of ruinous competition with new lines.

The authenticity of the startling reports which the London Hour is said to have quoted from the Berlin papers, to the effect that in the event of the failure of the Centennial Exhibition the goods of foreign exhibitors would be liable to seizure to meet the demands of the Commissioner's creditors, is officially denied by Hon. Alfred T. Goshorn Director General.

Few acts of Congress have excited so much general dissatisfaction among all classes of the community as that for which the public are indebted to Senator Hamlin, of Maine, and which is known as the new Postal law. The haste with which this enactment was passed and put into operation is regarded as a double hardship, and already thousands of complaints have been made of the unjust operation of the provisions of the bill.

There was a dullness and inertia apparent in the legislative proceedings of last night and to-day that is highly suggestive of the advent of Spring and the languid dolce far niente feeling which usually accompanies the first few days of warm weather.

BERLIN, March 16. In the lower house of the Prussian Diet to-day debate was opened on the first reading of the new Ecclesiastical bill.

That element of our uneasy population which delights to call itself the downtrodden masses has a new grievance. The harrowing circumstances are briefly these: One of the legacies of the defunct Board of Public Works for the District of Columbia was a claim of $75,000 for labor performed.

A large number of laborers gathered in the City Hall Park yesterday for the purpose of procuring employment on the public works, but they were unsuccessful. A few "tickets" entitling the holders to work were given out, and it is likely that more will be distributed to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, March 16. The Spanish Minister Senior Don Antonio Mantilla de los Rios, in full court dress, repaired to the Executive Mansion at noon to-day, by pre-arrangement, and delivered to the President, who was in company with the Secretary of State, the autograph letter of King Alfonso, of which the following is a translation:

Gen. FITZ JOHN PORTER has a record in the past which he is doubtless very desirous that the public should either forget or palliate. He made one fatal mistake in his life, which most men would have been content to expiate in silence and seclusion from public notice. Gen. PORTER is ambitious, however, and has chafed under the necessity of carrying through life with him the stain of disgrace.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 16. The Austin Powder Company's Mills, located near the canal, five miles south of this city, blew up this afternoon with a series of terrific explosions. The works, which consisted of ten or twelve buildings, were completely demolished, large fragments of timber and heavy machinery being thrown a considerable distance.

PARIS, March 16. When the Assembly met to-day the Duke D'Audiffret-Pasquier took the chair. He read an address containing some strongly-worded expressions against the Bonapartists, which were loudly cheered by the Left.

At the meeting of the Board of Police yesterday, Commissioner Disbecker, Chairman of the Committee on Street-cleaning, offered a resolution requesting the Board of Apportionment to transfer $100,000 from the street-cleaning fund of 1874 for the purpose of immediately cleaning the streets.

WASHINGTON, March 16. The Senate resumed the consideration of the resolution for the admission of Mr. Pinchback to-day, and Mr. ALCORN, of Mississippi, said he was one of the members of the Committee on Privileges and Elections, which signed the report in favor of a new election in Louisiana, but now he regarded the question of a new election in that State postponed indefinitely.
A stated meeting of the Board of Education will be held this afternoon at 4 o'clock.
John Fennerman was seriously injured yesterday by the explosion of a gun while shooting rats at his residence in Greenville. He was badly cut about the head and face.

I have just been favored with a view of a private letter received from the District of Cifuentes, near Sagua, and dated the 9th of March, in which the writer states that a party of some 200 or 300 well-mounted insurgents, under command of the insurgent Major General, the Pole, Carlos Roloff, has during the last few days been most actively engaged in destroying the plantations of the district near Sagua.

De Cornau, and A. Crane. The committee will report at a future meeting.

The regular semi-monthly meeting of the Board of Education was held yesterday afternoon. All the members were present except Commissioners Seligman, Beardslee, and Kelly. The most important of the reports submitted were those of the City Superintendent and the Agents of Truancy.

The new phase of the great railroad war yesterday made little or no change in the relative positions of either of the contesting roads. The orders of the Pennsylvania Central, New-York Central, and Erie lines to their agents were positive toadhere to the new schedule, while the agents of the Baltimore and Ohio line were left free as the winds to undercut the opposition tariff to any extent.

The memory of Ireland's patron saint was duly commemorated throughout the State of NewJersey yesterday by parades of societies and organizations. The parade in Jersey City was the largest and finest ever seen there. The line was formed on Jersey avenue, with the right resting on Newark avenue. At 10 o'clock the various societies arrived at this point, and at 11:30 the line was formed and the march up Jersey avenue to Hamilton Park begun.

The 11 o'clock night boat from Peek slip, for New-Haven has resumed her trips for the season.

The firm of Johnson Brothers Co., corner of Union square and University place, announce their Spring opening of millinery goods, laces, embroideries, French flowers and feathers, sash and trimming ribbons, dress silks and straw goods. Their assortment of hats and bonnets is perfectly charming and novel. Some of the latest fashions are remarkable, and very beautiful in design.

The excitement of the day has subsided and the town is quiet again; losses and incidents have been discussed and the immediate scene of the disaster looks almost deserted a light here and there shining from a window being the only sign of life visible where the flood was running a few hours ago.

Henry Vanholland, a book-binder by trade, was and still is employed to repair the maps and rebind the records of the Register's office. His engagement was by a committee of the Board of Supervisors, and was at the rate of $5 per day for himself and such assistants as he might find it necessary to employ.

When I was in France last Autumn ironical questions were put to me, from time to time, by my Republican friends, as to the health of "L'ecolier de Woolwich," who was also familiarly spoken of as "le Numero 37." From "Number 37" the "school-boy of Woolwich" has become "Number 7." You will have heard what an excellent examination he passed.

Samuel Ward, Jr., son of the Mr. "Sam" Ward whose testimony about the effect of good dinners in influencing Congressional legislation recently caused much attention, died in Paris Sept. 19, 1866. His father, unable, as claimed, to find that any will had been left by his son, took out letters of administration upon his son's estate, which was valued at about $40,000.

The procession was the main attraction to the Irish population, who thronged all the principal down-town streets during the hours in which it was in motion. In Second avenue, the Bowery, Canal street and other thoroughfares along the line of march, large-crowds gathered at an early hour, and the venders of miniature Irish flags and other national emblems drove a thriving trade.

LONDON, March 18. The Liverpool Spring meeting, commenced on Tuesday, was continued yesterday and to-day, and closes tomorrow, thus giving four days racing, under the Newmarket and Grand National rules. The most notable event of the meeting is the Grand National steeplechase, which took place to-day, and for which nineteen started, out of eighty-six subscribers, twenty-two of whom declared out, and each paid five sovereigns forfeit.

It is a singular fact in the intellectual history of this country that scientific associations do not succeed very well. Numerous societies are formed in different parts of the country for scientific objects, and no doubt accomplish considerable good; but they seldom take any very prominent position. The old "American Ethnological Society" of this City was an instance in point.

At about 10 o'clock this morning Mr. Carruth, the editor of the Vineland (N.J.) Independent, a weekly paper, was shot in the head and mortally wounded by Charles K. Landis, known throughout the southern section of the State of New-Jersey, from the fact that he founded the settlement, as the "Father of Vineland." He was formerly the editor of a Spiritualistic paper called the Moonly Voice.

The British Government some time ago issued a series of rather novel instructions to its representatives on the Continent of Europe. Although unusual in character, it was exceedingly simple, being nothing more than an order to collect information as to the earliest age at which marriages can be celebrated according to law in the various States.

NORWICH, Conn., March 19. The Republican campaign was opened in this city this evening, Hon. Julius C. Burrows, member of the Forty-third Congress from Michigan, making the address. It was expected that the meeting would in a great measure indicate the extent to which the awakened feeling in the Republican Party in Eastern Connecticut has gone, but no one anticipated such a gathering as assembled.

Its ability, pungency, and comprehensive grasp of a somewhat intricate subject, will surprise nobody unless, perhaps, the corrupt gang against whose system of plunder it is mainly directed. WASHINGTON, March 19. On account of the caucus of the Republican Senators, the Senate was not called to order to-day until 12:05 o'clock. Secretary Gorham then read a note from Vice President Wilson, dated March 18, stating he would leave the city that evening, and would not be present during the remainder of the session.
CHARLESTON, S.C., March 19. The trial of Treasurer Cardoza is in progress before the Legislature at Columbia. The argument of the counsel for the defense was concluded to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 19.--The caucus of Republican Senators reassembled this morning, and again after the executive session this evening. The last caucus lasted two hours. The Committee on Louisiana appointed yesterday reported that they could not agree. Over a dozen resolutions touching Louisiana affairs were offered in caucus.
Rev. William W.B. Newton, of Brookline, Mass., has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Trinity Episcopal Church in Newark.

WASHINGTON, March 18. In the Court of Commissioners of Alabama Claims to-day, in case No.643, Moses Hyneman vs. The United States, judgment was rendered in favor of the United States. This is the case of the general average founded upon the capture of the steam-ship Ariel by the Alabama, and her subsequent bonding, while on the voyage from New-York to Aspinwall.
First Lieut. Munson H. Beebe, of the Howitzer Battery, Eleventh Brigade, Brooklyn, has received the acceptance of his resignation.

LONDON, March 20. The thirty-second race between the Oxford and Cambridge University boat crews took place to-day over the usual course on the River Thames, from Putney to Mortlake, distance four miles and two furlongs, and for the first time in six years resulted in a victory for the Oxfords, and an easy one at that. The weather, though rather cold, was favorable for the race.

A cable dispatch announces the death of John Mitchel at Dromalane, near Newry, Ireland, yesterday morning. WASHINGTON, March 21.--The debate in the Senate will be resumed to-morrow at 12 o'clock, when Andrew Johnson takes the floor for what will undoubtedly be a long speech. He had a large number of books on his desk on Saturday, and has spent several hours to-day in the Congressional Library, from all of which the inference is easy that the exPresident has been "cramming" voraciously for the occasion.

This morning we print a very excellent map of the district which has been devastated by the Spring freshets. The valleys of the Delaware and Susquehanna have not been strangers to such visitations as those reported during the past week. According to a "military communication" in the Cologne Gazette, the Russian forces in Asia, if the Russo-Asiatic forces be alone taken into consideration, are not proportionate to the tremendous task undertaken there by Russia. Of reserves destined to take the field may be added a total of 25,750 men, and 9.650 horses.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 21.--At this point the river to-day is full of broken ice, but owing to the great width of the Susquehanna here there is no possibility of a gorge, even if a large mass of ice were to come down from Sunbury. HAZLETON, Penn., March 31.--Another crowd of armed men have started from Ebervale for Upper Lehigh to stop the men employed by the Jersey Central Railroad from loading coal at that place. The result of this raiding is awaited with great anxiety. Our local police is too small to contend with the exasperated miners, and it is expected that a call will be made for military aid.

It is difficult to define it clearly and briefly. That it is a contrivance for stealing we all know.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 2.--The Commissioners of Water-works are urged on every band to resign. The press of both parties has come out against them, and demanded that they shall prepare and make public a full report of the work and expenditures, and then resign. Under no circumstances will the people stand trifling or whitewash.

"Mignon" was last evening sung at the Academy of Music by Miss Kellogg, Mme. Van Zandt, Miss Beaumont, and Messrs. Castle and Peakes. The representation is the most effective the company has given this season, and it brought together last night the largest audience of the week, and elicited generous applause. To-day the too brief season of English opera closes with tho matinee recital of "The Talisman."

NEW-HAVEN, April 2.--Music Hall was crowded to-night to its atmost capacity with the awakened Repulicans of New-Haven, who had been got together without the help of cheap music and fireworks. There was nothing but the anannouncement that Hon. J. G. Blaine, of Maine, and Gen. Adam E. King, of Maryland would address the people; but it was more than sufficient; for late-comers had to be contented with standingroom.

At the meeting of the Board of Police yesterday a commnuication was received from the Board of Health calling attention to the frequent violations of section 55 of the Sanitary Code, which prohibits the driving of cattle through any street in this City except between 8 P.M. and two hours after sunrise the next morning. The matter was referred to the Superintendent for investigation.

A peculiarly idiotic bill has made its appearauce at Albany. It creates a commission for the survey of Harlem River and Spuyten Duyvil Creek, with the view of improving these streams for purposes of navigation. The bill names several engineers who shall compose the commission, allows them $2,500 for compensation, and appropriates $50,000 to carry out the survey.

The divorce suit of Andrew J. Odell against Annie E. Odell was continued yesterday before Judge Van Brunt, in Supreme Court, Special Term. The marriage is sought to be declared void on the ground that defendant, then being a married woman, was not legally divorced at the time of her marriage with plaintiff.

Macready's Reminiscences, edited by Sir Frederick Pollock, have appeared in London. Most American readers are likely to turn to the latter part of the second volume with the greatest interest. Therein we find narrated, in Macready's own words, the story of one of the strangest episodes in dramatic history--the "Macready riots," as they are called--which occurred in New-York in 1848, when the English actor visited this City.

ALBANY, April 2.--The capital seems almost deserted to-night, as nearly all the legislators left by the afternoon trains, as did also the Controller and other State officers. There is some doubt as to whether there will be a quorum in the Senate to-morrow, as some members who voted in favor of the Saturday session did not remain over.
The inquest into the cause of death of Lizzie Stern was continued yesterday by Coroner Creker and a jury, at the Coroner's office, Bellevue Hospital.

The arrangements for the dedication of the new Masonic Temple, corner of Sixth avenue and Twenty third street, which is announced to take place Wednesday, June 2, are steadily progressing. WASHINGTON, April 4--1 A. M.--Cloudy and cool weather continues, with light rain, on the New-England and Middle Atlantic coasts. Generally clear weather prevails in the remaining districts, with light to gentle winds and slight rise of temperature, except in the South Atlantic States. The Allegheny, the Ohio, the Central Mississippi, and the Arkansas Rivers have risen.

One of the most important bills reported during the last session of the French Assembly relates to the higher instruction of the people. No final decision has yet been reached, but much has been said on the necessity of amending the system now in operation. Nor was the debate confined to the committee room and legislative hall.

The epi The epidermis, or outer skin, grows with the greatest facility, just as the heir and the nails; it is indeed the saint tissue. The crystalline lens of the eye, which somewhat resembles the substance of the epidermis, is also reproduced when it is taken away. Many experiments made on dogs and rabbits, proved that this bi-convex lens, which is one of the principal organs of sight, is perfected afresh in a few months.

The worst fears of the rank and file of Tammany in relation to the patronage of the Department of Public Works have been realized. At first they feared the Swallow-tails, with Mayor Wickham as their leader, and they routed them, only to find a successful enemy (the Tammany Committee) seizing the spoils they were appointed to bestow.

HARTFORD, April 3. Hartford was aglow to-night with political excitement so great that rarely has a State campaign ended with such eclat. The Republicans were gatherd in the Opera-house and the Democrats in Allyn Hall, and both were crowded to suffocation; but as the former holds nearly twice as many people as the latter, the relative dimensions of the two meetings can be guessed.

In commencing my chronicle of the Parisian week, I feel like hurling a few invectives at the Spring of 1875 on account of the odious way in which it has disappointed all our hopes. Long before this date we had every reason to expect some bright and sunny days, and a sort of foretaste of the Summer to come; but up to this time we have seen nothing but sombre skies and chilling winds.

The weather of the past week has been sufficiently mild to induce a belief that the long-wished, for Spring has indeed returned, and the frost, which has bound the country in its icy fetters for three long and weary months, is rapidly exuding from the earth. The genial atmosphere brought its hopes and expectations, and human nature revels in the brightening prospects for business and pleasure.

WASHINGTON, April 4.--The Treasury Department is arranging to publish a volume exhibiting the financial transactions of the United States for the past one hundred years. The publication is designed as a contribution to the Centennial exhibition. The work will show the source and expenditure of every dollar, the causes that led to borrowing money at various times, together with a sketch of such debates in Congress as refer to the subject.

The weather has no influence on the attendance at Plymouth Church these days. The strike of the Cuban journeymen cigarmakers still continues, but like all similar strikes seems destined to a brief career. Mr. Lierena, Secretary of the Cuban Cigar Manufacturers' Association, stated yesterday that by the time the manufacturers required employes the strike would be at an end. Nearly all of the manufacturers have large stocks of cigars on hand, owing to the dull season and the small demand for high-priced cigars.

LONDON, April 8. Messrs. Moody and Sankey, the American revivalists, have declined propositions for the erection of a large hall in South London. There are two methods of dealing with the Indians. One is what may be called the manifest-destiny policy. This policy concedes to an Indian no rights which a white man or a white man's Government is bound to respect. It does not once say "turkey" to the Indian; it hardly is willing, in any division of the spoils of this continent, to give the red man the buzzard.

Miss Ncilson's engagement at Booth's Theatre was entered upon last evening with a performance of "Amy Robsart." An overflowing audience was present, and the recital passed off with much smoothness, and was attended with even more than the usual number of pleasant incidents marking successful nights. To many readers, "Amy Robsart" is, no doubt, a well-remembered work.

Reports are almost daily coming to the departments confirming what has been previously printed in THE TIMES of the character of the raids. The War and Post Office Departments particularly are receiving reports from their officers.

WASHINGTON, April 27.--Hundreds of persons remained at the scene of yesterday's railroad catastrophe until daylight this morning, watching the operations of the wreckers in removing the shattered care and locomotives, and supposing that there were bodies of victims in the rains yet to be discovered. All who here seriously wounded, however. had been carried to their homes or the Providence Hospital soon after the accident.

Edwards Pierrepont was born in North Haven, Conn., on March 4, 1817. The family from which he is descended is one of the best known in the annals of New-England, the first American of the name having settled in Roxbury, Mass., in the early part of the seventeenth century. Rev. James Pierrepont, a son, moved to New-Haven, Conn., in 1700 or thereabouts, and was one of the founders of Yale College.

In his frank and good-natured speech at the dinner given to Mr. SCHURZ on Tuesday night, Mr. MURAT HALSTEAD indulged in a reminiscence and review of the celebrated political failure of 1872. Since the candidate nominated at Cincinnati received the vote of scarcely a State in the Union, there can be no question as to the completeness of that failure.

A farewell banquet was given last night at Delmonico's to ex-Senator Carl Schurz, incident to his departure for Europe, by the German residents of this City. The entertainment was given as a supplement to the banquet of Tuesday night, and to express the approbation of the German citizens of his political course. The banquet was spread in the large dining hall, which was elaborately decorated.

At the Detroit House of Correction a year or ago, the high white-washed walls of the corridors were furnished with brackets and flower-pots to relieve the monotony and take away some of the gloom. One would scarcely think that the roughlooking, wicked men sent there for robbery, burglary, arson, and graver crimes, would have cared for the change, yet they gladly welcomed it.
A large number of men are being daily enlisted in this city for the Navy, and transferred to the receiving-ship Vermont.

The marriage of Senor M.E. de Rivas and Miss Nellie Murphy, the daughter of Hon. Thomas Murphy, was the social event of yesterday in this City, and the arrangements were on a scale of mag nificence which has seldom been equaled in NewYork. They were married by Cardinal McCloskey in St. Stephen's Church, and the number of invitations issued was only limited by the capacity of the church to accommodate the guests.

The prettiest and most elaborate ladies' fair which can be recalled in aid of a charitable undertaking is that which opened yesterday at the Armory of the Seventy-first Regiment, Broadway and Thirty-fifth street. Its purpose is to benefit the free training and cooking schools in connection with the Women's Educational and Industrial Society, and if zeal and good management can accomplish that object, it certainly should succeed.

LONDON, April 28.--At a reception given to M. Chevalier, the distinguished French economist, in Birmingham, this evening, Mr. John Bright made some remarks on free trade, in the course of which he said it was ludicrous for the United States to invite foreign manufacturers to compete at an exhibition, when a protective tariff prevented them from competing in American markets.

ALBANY, Wednesday, April 28, 1875. The subject which was most prominently be fore the Senate this morning, and for the longest time, was the bill introduced in the Assembly by Mr. Page, and providing that the Governor, with the consent of the Senate, shall appoint four Commissioners to investigate, consider, and report upon the disposition to be made of the lateral canals.

On Monday last at midday, as Mrs. Ellen Bishop, a lady stopping at the Pierrepont House, Brooklyn, was walking along Eighteenth street, in this City, from Sixth avenue to Broadway, she was attacked by a youthful ruffian named Peter Smith, alias Breckenridge, aged eighteen years. Smith seized Mrs. Bishop, and, having violently thrown her to the sidewalk, snatched a pocket-book containing $100 which the lady carried in her left hand.

At the meeting of the Board of Police yesterday, Commissioner Voorhis presented resolutions transferring from the Second, Third, and Twenty-eighth Precincts, to the First, Fourth, Fifth, Twenty-seventh, Eighth, Ninth, and Fifteenth Precincts, the quota of patrolmen agreed upon on Wednesday, in accordance with the resolution by which the firstnamed precincts were abolished.

The case of the Sylvan Dell and Shady Side, the former belonging to the Harlem and New-York Navigation Company, and the latter to the Morrisania Steam-boat Company, came yesterday before Mr. Addison Low, Supervising Inspector of Steam-boats, and on his suggestion an amicable arrangement was entered into between the two companies which should tend toward securing safe navigation for the future.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 30. A special dispatch to the Enquirer says: " A serious accident occurred on the Atlantic and Great Western Railroad, near Meadville, Penn., last evening. Two or three persons were killed and a large number of the passengers injured, some seriously. One sleeping car and one passenger coach were burned. The Convention of American Railway Master Mechanics met yesterday morning in the Cooper Institute, and, after a comparatively short session, finished its business for this year. Mr. H. M. Britton, of the association, occupied the chair, and there was a large attendance of members. Mr. Peter Cooper was a visitor, and, on the adjournment of the convention, he took its members through the several departments of the Institute.

It seems probable that the constitutional objections, to which we have already referred, will prove fatal to the operation of the General Rapid-transit bill recently passed. It is not unlikely that the Governor will refuse to allow the bill to become law, Under these circumstances, special interest attaches to the bill which was introduced yesterday by Mr. HUSTED, and has been made the special order in the Assembly for Monday evening.

The Philadelphia and Mutual Clubs came together in a match game for the first time this season. on the Union Grounds, yesterday, and the result was one of the most brilliant exhibitions of fielding skill ever seen in this vicinity. The Mutuals started off with the lead in the first inuing, they having made 2 runs against 1 for their opponents.

The State Senate would have done well not to have given the Governor a chance of vetoing such another bill as that providing for the regulation of Coroners' inquests, and "for the payment of services rendered by scientific persons as experts." We pointed out the objectionable features of this bill during its passage through the Assembly, and the Governor has unquestionable performed a public service in refusing to sign it.

By Judge Lawrence. Fry vs. Fry. I think that the County Clerk was entitled to a reasonable commission upon the amount deposited with him, and that the sum charged, $5, was reasonable commission. Motion denied without costs.

The banking-house of Alex. Frothingham Co., No. 12 Wall street, who deal in stock privileges, have paid this enormous sum to their customers during this short soace of time. Yesterday was the fourth day of the Spring meeting at Deerfoot Park, and a fine day's sport was bad. The weather was fine, and the track in excellent order for fast trotting. The first race called was the unfinished three-minute purse, postponed from the day before in consequence of darkness. Five heats had been trotted, Vulcan having two heats to his credit. Compeor one heat, and two dead heats with Harry Miller.
L. Frank, of No. 48 Courtlandt street, was held yesterday by Commissioner Shields, on a charge of selling liquor without payment of special tax.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 14. The races over the Association Course today were more largely attended than on any day during the meeting. The ladies' stand was thronged. The weather was superb and the track very fast.

DETROIT, May 14. The convention of the Social Science Association has terminated its labors, having really accomplished much, both as regards the health supervision of schools, the treatment of dependent and delinquent children, and the general cause of social reform. During this last day the Health Department had no session.

United States District Attorney Bliss has followed up the criminal prosecutions against the ring of silk smugglers by the initiation of civil proceedings to recover for the Government the ill-gotten gains it has been defrauded of. The rate of duty to which the hosiery and other fraudulent "sample" goods were subject was paid upon the costly silks which were smuggled.

Coroner Woltman yesterday concluded the inquest in the case of the four Costa children drowned by a collision between the steamer City of Hartford and the scow on which they lived, at Pier No. 24 East River, on the morning of the 3d inst. William Miner, Captain of the City of Hartford, testified: On Monday morning, the 3d inst., I came down the ....
Phillips Exeter Academy has 166 students on its rolls 40 Senior, 34 Middle, 39 Junior, and 53 Preparatory.

The Assembly at 1 o'clock to-day adjourned until Monday evening and the affair created no little surprise among the Republican Senators, and, in fact, among politicians and members generally. It was not generally supposed that the House would hold any session to-morrow, as its business was well advanced, but scarcely any one apprehended that it would take so long a recess.

Annie Vetter, aged six months, was smothered in bed yesterday morning at No. 4 Manhattan street.

LONDON, May 14. A dispatch to the Central News Association reports that the Inman Line steam-ship City of Brussels, which sailed from Liverpool yesterday, for New-York, has gone ashore on the Irish coast. Her passengers are all safe. The weather is fine.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 13. By the arrival of the steam-ship Cyphrenes advices have been received from Sydney to April 19, Auckland 16, and Honolulu, Sandwich Island, to the 4th of May.

The sixteenth Commencement of the Law School of the University of the City of New-York took place last evening at Steiuway Hall, which was crowded. Chancellor Howard Crosby presided. On the platform were ex-Judge Davies, formerly of the Court of Appeals; ex-Judge Peabody, Assistant Surrogate Van Schaick, Hon. Benjamin F. Willis. Prof. David R. Jaques, Edward S. Van Winkle, Smith E. Lane, Dr. Charles J. Pardee, and others.

WASHINGTON, May 14. In accordance with Article 1,072 of the Revised Regulations of 1874, the collection districts of the United States are arranged into divisions, to each of which a General Appraiser is assigned, who will supervise the appraisements, and discharge the other duties of his office exclusively within his division, unless otherwise instructed hereafter.

Woodward, Gen. Sbaler, Gen. McMahon, Col. Gildersleeve, Major Fulton, Capt. Bruce, and Mr. W.B. Coughtry. Capt. Bruce stated that he thought some action should be taken by the committee in reference to the proffer by the manager of the ...

The only sale made at the Exchange yesterday, Friday, May 14, was one by William Kennelly, who, by order of the Supreme Court, under direction of the Sheriff, disposed of a large plot of lots on East Eighty-sixth street, north side, 125 feet east of Second avenue, extending through to Eighty-seventh street, having a frontage on Eighty-sixth street of 280 feet, and on Eighty-seventh street of 169.7 feet.

VENT GARDEN. The silent process of dressing was only interrupted by the callboy Parsloe's voice, "Overture on, sir!" which sent a chill to my heart. The official rap at the door soon followed, and the summons. "Mr. Macready," made me instantly rally all my energies, and with a firm step I went forward to my trial.

On the upward-bound train on the Macon and Western Division of the Central Railroad from Griffin, yesterday, were Hon. A.H. Stephens, Col. Clisby, of the Macon Telegraph, and that fine old gentleman, Col. Cincinnatus Peeples, of this city.

RUTLAND, Vt., May 15. At an early hour this morning a fire broke out in Ripley Brick Operahouse block, in this city, and the building was entirely destroyed. The following particulars are from an extra of the Rutland Herald: "About 4 o'clock this morning an employe of the Herald discovered smoke issuing from Ripley's Opera-house block, on Merchants' row.

The Toronto Mail has a long description of the recent voyage of the steamer Polynesian, which left Liverpool, for Quebec, April 15, having on board forty-five cabin and 560 steerage passengers. We quote:

The dictates of fashion may be readily misrepresented when only some general ideas on the subject are obtained. A few words will suffice to explain how mistakes can be avoided. Great attention should be paid to the cut and shape of garments, trimmings should be used in moderation, glaring colors and showy styles ought to be avoided, and all that is eccentric and conspiouous studiously shunned.

OSCEOLA, Penn., May 15. There is little change to-day in the situation in the Clearfield mining region. The mines reported as not working yesterday, are still in the same condition, and there has been no acccession of force to the few still in operation on shortened time. A few miners truned out from the Stirling Mine yesterday, and by those on strike forty-two men are reported as ready to leave the Morrisdale Mine to-morrow.

Cincinnati must have looked rather desolate yesterday to those who remained there after the festival. The lights were fled, the garlands dead, the guests were all departed. They had had nearly a week of musical excitement, to say nothing of the preparatory fortnight; and, next to the issues of life and death, that is about as high a form of excitement as the soul can bear.

Francis Kelty, a coachman, residing on First avenue, who is thought to be of unsound mind, was hold at the Tombs Police Court yesterday, on a charge of drawing a loaded pistol on a claim agent named Nettleton, in the office of the latter, at No. 117 Broadway.
Gen. Daniel Butterfield and Commodore C. H. Garrison had a long interview yesterday with Mayor Wickham on the question of rapid transit.

On Tuesday last a dreadful scandal occurred in the House of Commons, from which the shaken nerves of society have hardly yet recovered. The Prince of Wales was actually turned out of the House of Commons, along with Prince Christian, the German Ambassador, and a number of other distinguished people. In this, however, no personal insult was leveled at his Royal Highness.

A further hearing in the case of Ida Maud templeton against her father-in-law, Col. William C. Templeton, to recover possession of her child, Willie C. Templeton, now in the possession of the defendant, was had yesterday in Supreme Court, Chambers, before Judge Donohue.

The appearance of the Memoirs of Gen. Sherman cannot fail to renew the intense interest felt in the events to which they chiefly relate during their progress, and we lay before our readers another installment of the absorbing narrative, giving as much as possible of the language of the distinguished author:

Upon each of the well-known ocean routes there is a favorite line of steamers, and "Everything" should be the answer to the query "What's in a name?" it asked in reference to the reputation of a mail steam-ship company. Like the Cunard-liners on the Atlantic, the Peninsular and Oriental Company's vessels have gained the name of being the safest and most comfortable steamers in which to travel eastward, or to Australia.

The adjournment of the Legislature will certainly take place before the close of this week. After agreement has been reached on the Supply bill, after a satisfactory Rapidtransit law has been passed, and after provision has been made for the reduction of this year's tax levy in New-York City, the people will be perfectly resigned to see both houses adjourned sine die.

Mayor Wickham held his usual weekly levee yesterday. It was attended by the Tammany legislators from this City. The list included Senator Moore, Assemblymen Daly, Campbell, and others. All the visitors seemed to be disheartened over their efforts at Albany.

A new scheme has been devised for perpetuating the union between Church and State in Great Britain. It consists in a proposal to abolish the traffic in livings, and to vest in the parishioners the inalienable right of presentation when a vacancy occurs.

An enthusiastic meeting of citizens advocating the interests of rapid transit was held in the Town Hall, at New-Rochelle, last night. The meeting was organized by the election of Mr. William Le Count as Chairman, and Mr. Elizur D. Griggs, Secretary. Mr. C.H. Roosevelt said that the meeting had been called for the purpose of manifesting the interest of the citizens in that locality in the progress of rapid transit.

Yesterday may fairly be considered as the opening of the yachting season at Prospect Park, Brooklyn. The weather was very fine, and the breeze not too strong, and, consequently, the boats on the lake had a first-rate opportunity to display their sailing qualities to good advantage.

This institution has just completed the first quarter of a century of its existence. In May, twenty-five years ago, Rev. L.M. PEASE first carried the Gospel into the Five Points, a district which, at that time, persons who had any regard for their own personal safety, rarely visited.

The present Government is now actively engaged in preparing the thirty-eighth law upon the press, and report says that some progress has been made during the week. It is a characteristic fact that each Government begins by making a new press law.

Reference has already been made in these columns to a cunningly-devised bill now before the committee of which Senator BOOTH is Chairman, in the Senate, having the innocent though complicated title of "An act to amend an act entitled an act to amend, consolidate, and reduce to one act the various acts relative to the common schools of the City of New-York."

During last week the Police arrested 1,861 persons. The Post Office deposits of the week from the sale of stamps were $59,600. President Jewett's Erie report was telegraphed in full to London yesterday.

I did not at all exaggerate the interest which the Detroiters take in the discussions of the Sociologists who are for the time being their guests. The authorities of the City Hall have very kindly loaned the use of several fine judicial chambers for the three departments, Health, Charity, and Finance, into which the association has temporarily divided itself.

For the first time this year the weather today favored a centennial, and the people of Westmoreland, Penn., had dry soil and bright sunshine wherewith to celebrate the heroism of those sturdy patriots who, 100 years ago to-morrow, declared that they were "possessed with the most unshaken loyalty and fidelity to his Majesty, King George III." Happily for them, history does not mention the names of these sturdy patriots.

"You have gone and done a fine thing, Master Johnny Ludlow!" The salutation came from Clerk Bumford. He was standing at the church door on Sunday morning, looking out as if he expected me, his fare pale and stern. I had run on betimes; in fact, before the bell began.

The American team practiced on the range at Creedmoor yesterday, for the fourth time since its selection. All the members were present, and some of the best individual scores were made that have been recorded this season.

The Atlantic Club of Brooklyn was badly defeated by the new Hartford nine on the Union Grounds yesterday. The game was the third of the series for the professional championship, and was witnessed by about 800 persons. Play was commenced at 3:40 P.M. with Mr. Martin, of the Nameless Club, as umpire. In the first inning the Hartfords were easily disposed of without scoring.
A member of Parliament has been fined $351 in a London court for allowing the sewage of his house to flow into the river Lea.

The following are additional particulars relating to the natives of Davenport, Iowa, who were lost on board the Schiller; Of nineteen passengers from Davenport and its vicinity only three were saved namely, John Jones and wife and Charles Frahm. Among the lost was Otto Kircher.

The Spring meeting at Deerfoot Park was concluded yesterday with the postponed 2:45-purse and a match of a mile and repeat between Lippencott and Cranky Jake. In the 2:45-purse there were ten entries, and five of them started. In the pools Harry Miller was the favorite at $20, Dan Ford $10, and the field $14.
The total amount of taxes received during the past week was $46,559. The number of arrests made during the past week by the Brooklyn Police was 472.

The resignations of Adjt. August Bickel and First Lieut. John G. Loserre, of the Third Regiment Cavalry, have been accepted.

Bright Summer weather has at length come, and the Champs Elysees have had their opening day. The cafe concerts are once more attracting the usual crowds, the circus has changed its domicile, and M. Betsselievre has opened his garden to continue the legend of Musard.

Of the 183 students at Wesleyan University, 148 are professors of religion, and of these forty-eight have already received license to preach. The present Senior class numbers forty-five, and of these all but six are professors of religion.
Jacob Levi, aged 9 years, of No. 149 Second street, was run over and fatally injured by a horse and carriage driven by William Livingston, of No. 323 West Twenty-first street, who was arrested.

The tenth Convention of the Social Science Association is now a thing of the past. It must be conceded that though in such an institution doctrinaires of the most impracticable character got a famous opportunity to buzz the world, yet there is an immense amount of sound, practical work fairly achieved at these meetings.

Although Italy has been almost the last to take action with refererence to the Philadelphia Exposition, yet she has now begun in earnest, and there is time enough, and there can be no doubt that she will make a display worthy of her new life of commercial activity and the reputation she has always enjoyed of being one of the principal seats of the arts.
Rev. R.T. Pearson has resigned the Pastorate of Trinity Episcopal Church at Hewletts. The opening of the Manhasset House at Locust Point has been fixed for Thursday, June 10.

In the month of September last I gave you a report of the "Affaire Perkins" which then came before the Eighth Chamber of Police Correctionnelle, and then intimated that the plaintiff in the suit was not satisfied with the judgment,which condemned Perkins to a year's imprisonment and acquitted his wife.

In the Clearfield mining region of Pennsylvania there are twenty collieries, capable of turning out between five and six thousand tons of coal per day. At the time of the strike these mines were employing a large force, paying at the rate of fifty cents per ton to the miners.
John Robinson was arrested yesterday afternoon for complicity in the burglary of Mrs. McAleer's premises, on North Fifth street, April 16. The other parties are in jail awaiting trial.

The Pacific Mail steamer Alaska, from Hong Kong, via Yokohama, arrived at San Francisco yesterday. Dennis Lynch, of Worcester, Mass., died on Saturday from injuries received by being kicked last Tuesday during a fight by Patrick Cronin, who is under arrest.

WASHINGTON, May 16. Attorney General Pierrepont is understood to have tendered the position of Assistant Attorney General, made vacant by the resignation of Mr. Hill, to a gentleman whose name has not yet been made known.

The Paris correspondent of the London Times writes April 30: Stories of robberies are always amusing for those who have not been the victims. A few days ago a Parisian jeweler was the victim of a robbery to the amount of 106,000 francs, organized with rare audacity and persistency.

The furniture factory of Gunther Fink, Nos. 9 and 11 Edward street, Baltimore, Md., was burned last evening. Loss estimated at $15,000, of which $6,000 is on furniture, insured as follows: In Lycoming and Meridan, (Penn.,) companies, New-Orleans Fire Insurance, and Royal Canada, $2,500 each; Standard, New-Jersey, and Bangor, Me., $1,500 each; People's, New-Jersey, $500; Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, $750. Total, $14,250. The same firm were burned out a few months ago.

The Senatorial contest in New-Hampshire is not yet settled. The question is still the probable action of the Governor and Council, and nobody knows what everybody is dying to find out. It is by no means likely that even his Excellency and associates in office have decided upon the course they propose to take in this highly important matter.

If persons who decide to build themselves homes in the West, and to seek wealth by cultivating the soil, would always appoint special committees from their own number to visit the States in which they propose to settle, and make purchases of land in their behalf, there would be no need for calling attention to the operations of swindlers.

OSCEOLA, Penn., May 16.--Perfect quiet reigns in the Clearfield mining region to-day. The miners on strike have not held any meetings, and as most of the operators reside in Philadelphia, it is not known at this point what action they are taking today.

WASHINGTON, May 17. Secretary Bristow, and those operating with him, are not communicative in regard to the probable evidence that another blow is to be struck within the ensuing fort-eight hours, the force of which will be felt in the East and in Kentucky.

Transactions in real estate in Brooklyn since the close of the annual renting season have been in the main marked by dullness, even for a time when activity in genuine sales is not looked for among those who are engaged in its interest.

The House of Commons is to rise for the Whitsantide holidays on Thursday next, and it is hoped that it will, after a brief interval for rest and reflection, come together again in a more vigorous state of mind than it has exhibited during the previous part of the session.

The Unitarian Local, or New-York and Hudson River Conference, held its opening meeting last evening at the Second Unitarian Church, corner of Clinton and Congress streets, Brooklyn, of which Rev. John W. Chadwick is Pastor.

An attempt was made to-day to revive the bill which was lost about a fortnight since, and which provided for the payment to John H. Brady of something like $12,000, claimed by him to be due for work done by him nine years ago in paving Broadway below Fourteenth street.
Gen. John C. Breckinridge died of abscess of the liver, combined with consumption. His last hours were quiet and peaceful.
